table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used when referring to disruptors ({nISwI':n}), and is distinct from {baH:v}. The object of this verb is the {tIH:n:1} "energy beam" which is fired, for example, {nISwI' tIH bach}. In practice, the word {tIH:n:1,nolink} is commonly dropped, and one simply says {nISwI' bach} instead.[2]
{baH:v:nolink} is pronounced like the name of the Terran composer "Bach".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the first word in the Klingon-English side of the dictionary portion of {KGT:src}, where it is incorrectly listed as a noun as a joke.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word is used when referring to torpedoes, and is distinct from {bach:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "badge" is something that has to be earned.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: companion, darling, dear, lover, mate, partner, romantic

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used to signal surrender in a duel.

table.name: mem
table.column: toss bat'leth from one hand to the other

table.name: mem
table.column: be fresh, be just picked (fruit, vegetable)

table.name: mem
table.column: She is the actress who plays {lurSa':n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: honor (general, philosophical concept, associated with integrity)

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: You will be remembered with honor.

table.name: mem
table.column: An honorable death requires no vengeance.
An honourable death requires no vengeance.

table.name: mem
table.column: batlh potlh law' yIn potlh puS.
Honor is more important than life.
Honour is more important than life.

table.name: mem
table.column: A Klingon does not postpone a matter of honor.
A Klingon does not postpone a matter of honour.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {batlhHa' vanglu'taHvIS quv chavbe'lu'.:sen} ▶ {Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchugh, qoj matlhHa'chugh, pagh ghaH SuvwI''e'.:sen}
dishonourably, dishonored, dishonoured, without honor, without honour

table.name: mem
table.column: One does not achieve honor while acting dishonorably.
One does not achieve honour while acting dishonourably.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being orbited. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The {yor:n} of a {qach:n}, and the top face of a {pa' beb:n}.
"Babe Ruth" was an American baseball player.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who lays out the shingles, planks, etc., when constructing a roof.

table.name: mem
table.column: Two common kinds of {beH:n} are {nISwI' beH:n} and {pu'beH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be sure, be definite, be positive, be certain

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chobelHa'moH, DI'qar. SajlIj 'oHbe' quvwIj'e'.:sen:nolink} "You disappoint me, D'Kar. My honor is not your play-thing."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, instead of saying "I am X years old", one's age is expressed by saying "I was born X years ago."[2]
▶ {loSmaH ben jIboghpu'.:sen:nolink} "I am 40 years old."[2] ▶ {cha'vatlh ben HIq:n}[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: A rank given to enlisted personnel in the Defense Force ({Hubbeq:n}).
A crewman is at "beck" and call.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of mineral, bekpuj (orange in color)
This word may contain the element {puj:n:hyp} also found in {cha'puj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of an opera, play, story, speech)

This refers to the final section of a performance (last aria in an opera, last speech in a play, last sentence or so in a story or speech, etc.). For a song (and only for a song), the final portion is called its {'o'megh:n}.
This is, of course, a reference to Bertram from Shakespeare's "All's Well That Ends Well".

table.name: mem
table.column:
The elements of the name of this weapon are archaic, but it means "sword of honor". In modern Klingon, of course, "sword of honor" would be {batlh 'etlh:n:nolink}. In Klingon legend, the original Sword of Honor was forged by {qeylIS:n}. See {paq'batlh:n}.
The {betleH:n:nolink} is also called the {betleH quv:n:nolink}, to differentiate it from the similar sounding {meqleH:n}.
This word is misspelled {batleH:n:hyp,nolink} on {SkyBox 8:src}.[3] A message on the {s.k:src} newsgroup gives a bit of history behind the various spellings used in English for this word.[4]

▶ {qaStaHvIS wa'maH puq poHmey, wo'rIv betleH ghaj qorDu'Daj. nuja' tlhIngan wIch ja'wI'pu' yIntaHvIS qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay' batlh 'etlhvam chenmoHlu'pu'.:sen:nolink} "Worf's bat'telh has been in his family for ten generations. According to Klingon legend, this sword of honor descends from the time of Kahless the Unforgettable."[3]
batleth, bat'telh, sword of honor, sword of honour

table.name: mem
table.column: "Bay" is an English word with the same meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression is known only through the sentence, from {SkyBox 31:src}, {beyHom bey bey'a' jachtaH latlh tlhInganpu'.:sen:nolink} "[Other Klingons] roar in a great crescendo."[1] Its exact grammar is unclear.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a financial establishment.
"Bailey Banks and Biddle" is the name of a chain of jewellery stores.

table.name: mem
table.column: Known types of {bey':n:nolink} include the {betleH bey':n}, the {quv bey':n}, and the {nuH bey':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Sister of Lursa and Duras. She is portrayed by the actress {ghuwI'nItlh wa'lIS:n:name}.

▶ {DuraS tuq tlhIngan yejquv patlh luDub 'e' reH lunIDtaH DuraS be'nI'pu' lurSa' be'etor je. ngoQvam luchavmeH ghawran maghpu' be'nI'pu'. woQ luSuqmeH jIjpu' chaH romuluSngan'e' je.:sen:nolink} "The sisters of the House of Duras, Lursa and B'Etor, are constantly seeking a higher standing for the House of Duras within the Klingon High Council. To this end, the sisters have acted against Gowron, going as far as to work with Romulan factions in order to gain power."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Federation. Its inhabitants are telepaths.

table.name: mem
table.column: The medical abbreviation "b.i.d.", short for the Latin "bis in die", means "twice a day".

table.name: mem
table.column: For notes on the grammar of this sentence, see {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: Jail is referred to in slang as the "big house".

table.name: mem
table.column: If you are afraid to die, you have already died.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you say the wrong thing, I will kill you.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined on {TKD p.172:src} as "Be quiet! (i.e., Stop speaking!)", and in {PK:src} as "Shut up!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This sentence literally means, "If you don't surrender, you will die". Note that even though the English translation has "or" in it, the conjunction {pagh:conj} is not used in the Klingon sentence. In general, English sentences of the form "X or Y!" (demanding that the listener choose one out of the two options) must be recast as {bI-X-be'chugh vaj bI-Y:sen:nolink} "If you don't X, you will Y" in Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is often said by Klingon merchants to their customers. See the similar {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen} for analysis.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you cannot fail, you cannot succeed.

table.name: mem
table.column: second tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n:nolink}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: May you encounter Kahless in your dreams.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {bIS'ub:n} and {pIrmuS:n} for the bottom parts of an object. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the Klingon word for "hundred thousand" is independent of the words for "hundred" ({vatlh:n}) and "thousand" ({SaD:n}). Thus, {bIp:n:num,nolink} is equivalent to "lakh" which is used in South Asian numbering systems on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: Water is used as the symbol of weakness and disdain. This idea is expressed in the Klingon idiom {puj; bIQ rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a verb with one of each type of suffix. It doesn't really mean anything.
The invention of this verbal phrase is attributed to Mark Shoulson.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for a ship that travels on water.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the room in which Terrans spray themselves with water. (Yuck.)

table.name: mem
table.column: Brackish water is the best water for tea.[1, p.96]

table.name: mem
table.column: be quite mistaken, be totally wrong
This literally means "The cup contains water." It is a reasonably strong expression, and it would not be surprising if a fight broke out after this is uttered.

table.name: mem
table.column: To really succeed, you must enjoy eating poison.

table.name: mem
table.column: bIQongtaHvIS nItlhejchugh targhmey bIvemDI' nItlhej ghIlab ghewmey.
If you sleep with targs, you'll wake up with glob flies.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {SIqral bIQtIq:n}[2] ▶ {QIStaq qul bIQtIqHomDaq 'etlhDaj vo' nuch} "The coward throws his sword into the fire streams of Kri'stak"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The sword is in the ocean.
This idiom means that something has ended, and it is impossible to return to the previous condition.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means the edge ({HeH:n}) of the ocean ({bIQ'a':n}). Presumably, a beach by a lake would be called a {ngeng HeH:n:nolink} (from {ngeng:n} meaning "lake"), and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {bIr; bortaS rur}.
A cold "beer", or alternatively, "brrrr" is the sound one makes when one is cold.

table.name: mem
table.column: The blood of the warrior grows cold.

table.name: mem
table.column: If the qIvon is cold, the blood is hot.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremony in which the killer of the head of a Klingon house marries the widow and becomes the head of the house himself. The language associated with this ceremony is in a form of {no' Hol:n}.[1, p.11]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon by itself, but can be inferred from {bIreQtagh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you must negotiate, watch your enemy's eyes.

table.name: mem
table.column: For example, this word would be used to describe the inside bottom of a box. The other face of the box's {bIS'ub:n:nolink} is its {pIrmuS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {bIt; tI'qa' vIghro' rur}.[2]
As the saying goes: once bitten, twice shy. On {KGT p.132:src}, the word is written as {tIb:v:nolink} instead of {bIt:v:nolink}, but this is clearly a typo.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you cannot be shamed, you cannot be honored.
If you cannot be shamed, you cannot be honoured.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiomatic expression, {pe'vIl bI'chu':sen} "forcefully sweep away", which means to do something all at once, as a single event.[1, p.112]
{romuluSnganpu' Dujmey DIQaw'pu'; pe'vIl DIbI'chu'pu'.} "We destroyed the Romulans' ships all at once."

table.name: mem
table.column: This sentence doesn't appear in canon. It is here for symmetry with {bImoHqu'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: beginning (of an opera, play, story, speech)
This refers to the opening section of a performance (first act, scene, sentence, etc.).
These are the first two syllables of the Torah.
▶ {bI'reS qeylIS vaq molor:sen:nolink} "First, Molor taunts Kahless"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to you (plural)".

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {boch; ghIch rur}.[2, p.133]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is derived from an earlier expression {'etlh bochmoHwI':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: Klingons are born, live as warriors, then die.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {Honor Bound:src}, this is an animal native to {boretlh:n}, which makes bleating sounds and tends to run around in circles.

table.name: mem
table.column: Possibly from "boll weevil", from American Civil War history.

table.name: mem
table.column: Kinds of {bom:n:nolink} include: {bang bom:n}, {HIjve' bom:n}, {van bom:n}, {chon bom:n}, {Dap bom:n}, {may' bom:n}, {najmoHwI':n}

table.name: mem
table.column: The memory of you sings in my blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a Klingon idiom, {'oj; bomwI' rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The refrain to the Hokey Pokey, "that's what it's all about", is {'e' bop:sen:nolink} in Klingon.
{HolQeD bopbe' paqvam.} "This book is not about linguistics."

table.name: mem
table.column: ally with, form an alliance with; add (used in math)
The four basic arithmetic operations are: + {boq:v:nolink}, - {boqHa':v}, * {boq'egh:v}, / {boqHa''egh:v}. In these operations, numbers are treated as if they are grammatically singular.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha'logh boq'egh wej; chen jav:sen:nolink} 2 x 3 = 6 ▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice."

table.name: mem
table.column: Its livers are eaten as {boqrat chej Qevlu'pu'bogh:n:nolink} "stewed bokrat liver".
{boqrat chej:n:nolink} is listed in the glossary to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who assists someone.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This specifically refers to the sound that a stomach makes.

table.name: mem
table.column: a very small bird whose eggs are considered quite tasty

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {bIr; bortaS rur}.
▶ {bortaS nIvqu' 'oH bortaS'e'.:sen} ▶ {bortaS bIr jablu'DI' reH QaQqu' nay'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: bortaS bIr jablu'DI' reH QaQqu' nay'.
Revenge is a dish which is best served cold.

This is a very famous Klingon proverb.
There is also a related idiom {bIr; bortaS rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The German word for "forbidden" is ver"bot"en.
▶ {Dubotchugh yIpummoH.:sen}[2] ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to device that generates the force field ({Surchem:n}) surrounding a spaceship. For hand-held shields, see {yoD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the area between two (or more) objects, see {joj:n}. For the interior of an object in general, see {qoD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to remove food from {'un:n}.
This word is used in the idioms {bo'Dagh'a' lo':sen} and {bo'DaghHom lo':sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression has the negative connotation of exaggerating when it is inappropriate to do so.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression has the negative connotation of minimizing the importance of something when it is inappropriate to do so.

table.name: mem
table.column: bird, the most general word for a bird-like creature

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Klingon Empire. According to Klingon mythology, it is here that {qeylIS:n} will return.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon Dictionary was published by Pocket Books. See also {paq:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to an internal organ, of which Klingons have two (see {bIraqlul:n}). To refer to the exterior midsection of the body, use {chor:n:1} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: The K-E side says [kud] instead of [qud].

table.name: mem
table.column: concentrate on, focus on, think only about

table.name: mem
table.column: quality that is similar to what humans call "gall"
This is an admirable trait to have.

table.name: mem
table.column: Admire the person with dirt under his fingernails.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {rav:n:2} (def'n 2) for an example of how to talk about classified information.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the "secret information" sense of "classified", see {pegh:v:2} (def'n 2). See also {rav:n:2} (def'n 2) for an example of how to talk about classified information.

table.name: mem
table.column: This cannot be used to say that a person is "full" (i.e., not hungry).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: good news, it's good to hear that

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the highest rank of {QaS:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word or a homophone appears to be a component of {lolSeHcha:n} and {'eDSeHcha:n}, which suggests that perhaps {cha:n:nolink} can mean "rockets" in some contexts, or used to in the past.

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang term derives from the similarity in the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect of {chab:n:1} (def'n 1) to {cham:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "new pie". This slang term derives from the similarity in the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect of {chab:n:1} (def'n 1) to {cham:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was originally defined as "emergency" in {TKD:src}, and its meaning was then expanded to include "auxiliary, backup" in a vocabulary list first published in {veS QonoS:src} then reprinted in {HQ 1.3, Sept. 1992:src}. Note that a noun-noun construction containing {chach:n:nolink} might have a different meaning depending on whether {chach:n:nolink} is the first or second noun in the compound.

table.name: mem
table.column: close female friend of a female

table.name: mem
table.column: In the novel {Sarek:src}, {chal:n:nolink} is also the name of a type of flower.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Romulan Star Empire.
The fact that the name of this planet appears to be "inhabited sky" in Klingon (see {chal:n}, {toq:v}) seems to be a coincidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is in the direction of the sunrise.[1] It is 90 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.
China is in the east (from the perspective of Europe or America).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is kept in a large {bal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a regional word for {qettlhup:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Chang and Eng Bunker were a famous pair of Siamese twins.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's quite common for the backs of one's hands to become "chap"ped.

table.name: mem
table.column: thrust upward with end of bat'leth

table.name: mem
table.column: There have been a number of conquerors named Charles.

table.name: mem
table.column: top of walking cane or ceremonial cane

table.name: mem
table.column: This is served in a {maHpIn:n}, and eaten in a {Duq:n}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word is used for a broader range of objects than the translation "permit" suggests. Kinds of {chaw':n:nolink} include {HIjmeH chaw':n}, {Huch chaw':n}, {leng chaw':n}, {lojmIt chaw':n:nolink}, {yer ghajwI' chaw':n}, and {'elmeH chaw':n}. Thus, {chaw':n:nolink} can also mean "ticket" or "pass".
This is missing from the K-E side of {TKD:src}.
{cha'puj vIngevmeH chaw' HInobneS.} "Give me a permit to sell dilithium, your honor."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: {chay' jura'?} "What are your orders?", or literally, "How do you (sing.) command us?"

table.name: mem
table.column: How did this happen? What's going on?

table.name: mem
table.column: How do I use this? What do I do with this?

table.name: mem
table.column: The first ever line of Klingon spoken on-screen was {wIy cha'}, in {Star Trek I:src}.
{tlhIngan Dujmey law'qu' SommeyDaq batlh cha'lu'.} "[It] has been emblazoned upon the hulls of countless Klingon Starships."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird noted for its speed

table.name: mem
table.column: During some legal proceedings, the accused must have a second to defend him or her.

table.name: mem
table.column: a species of Klingon bird about which little is known

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons have twenty-three ribs ({joQ:n:2,body}). This expression means that something is not quite right.
▶ {naDev cha'maH cha' joQDu' tu'lu':sen:nolink} (this means something strange is going on) ▶ {cha'maH cha' joQDu' ghaj qama':sen:nolink} "The prisoner has twenty-two ribs", i.e., he's a bit strange

table.name: mem
table.column: a small bird which digs up bugs to eat

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird noted for its song

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha'puj tlhIlHal vISuch vIneH.} "I want to visit the dilithium mines."[2] ▶ {cha'puj vIngevmeH chaw' HInobneS.} "Give me a permit to sell dilithium, your honor."[3] ▶ {yuQ SumDaq cha'puj law' Datu'.} "Detect large sums of dilithium on nearby planet."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: Crude dilithium crystal is called {Dom:n}.[1] Chrystalline dilithium is used as the reaction moderating element ({choH lISbogh Hap'e':n}) in a Klingon Bird of Prey.[2] The verb {chIm:v} is used for a drained dilithium crystal.[3]
▶ {cha'pujqutmey vIje' vIneHbej!} "I definitely want to buy dilithium crystals!"[4] ▶ {cha'pujqutmey chIm lutamlu'.} "Drained dilithium crystals are replaced."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird with a noisy, repetitive cry
A "cuckoo", as in a cuckoo clock.

table.name: mem
table.column: This ale is too potent for tourists.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that this word is singular, unlike the English word "scissors".

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "we hit targets". Note that {DoSmey:n:nolink} must be used, not the inherent plural {ray':n}. This idiom can be shortened to just {DoSmey DIqIp.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression means that two people are involved in a single activity and no one else is. For example, a duel may be described by saying {Suv cha' qabDu':sen:nolink} "Two faces are fighting", "Two people are fighting one-on-one".
one on one, one-on-one, face to face, face-to-face

table.name: mem
table.column: unit of weight, mass (approx. 5 lbs or 2.25 kg)
Since gravity on Kronos is different than that on Earth, it's not really clear what the exact value of this unit is, or whether it measures weight or mass.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the {BoP:src} poster, 8.7KT = 375 000 {cheb'a':n:nolink}. It is likely that one {cheb'a':n:nolink} is equal to nine {cheb:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: An alcoholic beverage best served heated and steaming.[1] Its name appears to be composed of {chech:v} and {tlhutlh:v}.[2]
In the K-E side, this is given as "baceh'tluth". This is commonly assumed to be a typo, or perhaps a joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the place to which the subject returns (if it is not mentioned, the verb takes a prefix indicating no object). If the return is forced, use {tatlh'egh:v} instead.[5]

▶ {ghorgh pa'wIjDaq jIchegh?} "When can I return to my room?"[2] ▶ {wa'leS jIchegh.} "Tomorrow I will return."[3] ▶ {DaH machegh.}[4]
The following four examples illustrate the role of the object(s) and how to use {chegh:v:nolink} with {-Daq:n} and {-vo':n}[5]: ▶ {lupDujHomDaq jIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return on the shuttle." ▶ {lupDujHom vIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the shuttle." ▶ {lupDujHomDaq may'Duj vIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the battle cruiser on the shuttle" ▶ {tera'vo' Qo'noS vIchegh.:sen:nolink} "I return to Kronos from Earth"

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons have two livers.[1, p.28] (See also {bIraqlul:n}.)

table.name: mem
table.column: For the mathematical operation of addition, see {boq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The element {chem:n:hyp,nolink} is not known to appear by itself, but is found in the words {HoSchem:n}, {peQchem:n}, {pIvchem:n}, and {Surchem:n}.
In {TKDA:src}, {peQ chem:n:nolink} actually appears as two words (with a space).

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used to indicate the result of mathematical operations.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the verb {chen:v} with the suffix {-moH:v}, so verb suffixes of types 1 to 3 need to go before {-moH:v}, which is type 4.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: General Chang ({cheng Sa':n:nolink}) was a character in {Star Trek VI:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?
Tickle us, do we not laugh? Prick us, do we not bleed? Wrong us, shall we not seek revenge?
This is a paraphrase of a famous passage from Shakespeare's {The Merchant of Venice:src}, Act III, scene i.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word sounds like "chair", but {che':v} is closer in meaning to "chair".

table.name: mem
table.column: In the dialect of {voSpegh Sep:n}, this refers to any coat or jacket (what other Klingons would call a {wep:n:1} (def'n 1)).

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {lo'laHbe'; chetvI' chIm rur}.
The distinction between a {chetvI':n:nolink} and a {DuS:n} has to do with how the projectile is loaded.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a stick with a hook at the end, which is used as an aid in throwing (see {wob:v}) a {tlhevjaQ:n}.
This item, as described in {KGT:src}, would seem to be an "atlatl".

table.name: mem
table.column: The expression {Dujmey law' chIjpu':sen:idiom} means that somebody is experienced.

table.name: mem
table.column: The idiomatic expression {DoS chIl:sen:idiom} means "to digress", e.g., {DoS vIchIl:sen:nolink} means "I digress".

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {chIm:v} is used for a drained dilithium crystal.
▶ {cha'pujqutmey chIm lutamlu'.} "Drained dilithium crystals are replaced."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: stairway leading to a door of a ship, gangplank

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This can also refer to a chemical or nuclear reaction.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears on the {BoP:src} poster in the specification: {choH lISbogh Hap'e' - cha'pujqut:sen:nolink} "Reaction Moderating Element - Crystalline Dilithium".

table.name: mem
table.column: close in, get closer, come nearer

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unknown why this word appears to combine {chol:v} and {jaH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In a Klingon bar, the bartender shouts {'eb Qav:n} for "last call".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be profound, be thorough, be careful; be good, be excellent
This word is applied to a person's intellect, and expresses a meaning equivalent to {Qubchu'}. It is also used by itself as an expression of approval, similar to {maj:excl}.[1, p.148]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is almost a "chomp".
In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", the British expression "Give us a kiss, love." was translated as {HIchop, bang.:sen:nolink}[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2] ▶ {wo' ngay' bochoqmeH bowIvlu'pu'!:sen:nolink} "You have been chosen to preserve the glory of the Empire!"[3].

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha' vI' vagh choQmey lutoghlu':sen:nolink} "Number of Decks: 2.5"[1] ▶ {cha' choQmey naQ tu'lu' 'ej tep choQ bIngDaq lo' law' bID choQ tu'lu':sen:nolink} "2 Full Decks and a Half Utility Deck under the Cargo Deck"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the exterior midsection of the body. To refer to a stomach (an internal organ), use {burgh:n} instead.
This is defined in {TKD:src} as "belly".[1] The gloss "midsection" comes from {FTG:src}.[2]
▶ {tajwIj 'oHbe' chorlIj jeqbogh Dochvetlh'e'.:sen:nolink} "That is not my dagger protruding from your midsection."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {bargh:n} made of ceramic. This word can also be shortened to {chor:n:2,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: eighth tone of nonatonic music scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2,nolink}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that there are two twilights in a day ({jaj:n}), one in the morning and one in the evening.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. However, it follows the pattern of the other {tay:n} words, and is included here for reference.

table.name: mem
table.column: throw (a spear) at, hurl (a spear) at
This verb can only be used if the projectile is or resembles a spear. The object of this verb is the intended target.[1, p.64]

table.name: mem
table.column: explain clearly to, clarify for, specify for

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {ghu':n} can be used to refer to a proposal (a proposed situation); that is, one can {chup:v} a {ghu':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary of {A Burning House:src}, this is a rodent that mostly lives underground and makes an annoying noise.

table.name: mem
table.column: This seems to be composed from {chuS:v} and {'ugh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is plural, but it is unknown if the singular form {chuv:n:hyp,nolink} exists. There is, however, a verb {chuv:v}.
The {chuvmey:n:nolink} include pronouns, numbers, conjunctions, adverbials, and exclamations.

table.name: mem
table.column: The noun {chuyDaH:n} seems to imply that this verb, or a homophone, can be used to describe the expulsion of gas at a high velocity.

table.name: mem
table.column: Types of thrusters include {'eDSeHcha:n}, {lolSeHcha:n}, {muDDaq 'eDSeHcha lulaQlu'bogh:n}, {Hong boq chuyDaH:n}, and {'o' chuyDaH:n}.
{DaH:n} appears to be "array", and {chuy:v:nolink} may be related to the verb "to sneeze".

table.name: mem
table.column: The glossary to {A Burning House:src} claims that {chu'wI':n:nolink} meaning "trigger" is also slang for "rookie", "beginner", or "newbie". See {chu':v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: behave as, act in the manner of

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to you".

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, when one lives at a place, he or she is thought of as occupying or inhabiting it. That is, he or she is not seen as doing something at a location, but rather as doing something to it.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be not attentive, be distracted, lack focus
This applies to a person who is not focused on the task at hand.[1, p.149]

table.name: mem
table.column: I must wash my hair now.
This is something you might say to turn down someone's romantic overtures.

table.name: mem
table.column:
While both {DaHjaj:n:nolink} and {jajvam:n} mean "today", they are not quite interchangeable. {DaHjaj:n:nolink} (but not {jajvam:n}) is used as the time element in a sentence: {DaHjaj romuluSngan vIHoHpu':sen:nolink} "today I killed a Romulan".[3]
As the subject of a sentence, {jajvam:n} is more typically found, though {DaHjaj:n:nolink} is not impossible. Compare: ▶ {nI' jajvam:sen:nolink} "this day is long" ▶ {nI' DaHjaj:sen:nolink} "today is long"[3]
{DaHjaj:n:nolink} also behaves as a noun in such noun-noun constructions as {DaHjaj gheD:n} "today's prey", a term often heard in Klingon restaurants with a meaning comparable to "catch of the day".[3]
{DaHjaj:n:nolink} is also used with words indicating a time of day to refer to that portion of the current day. For example, {DaHjaj ram:n}, literally "today's night", means "tonight".[3]
As a time element, {DaHjaj:n} precedes any adverbials.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: dish in a restaurant, "catch of the day"

table.name: mem
table.column: May you die before you are captured.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chenmoHlu'meH Daq:n} ▶ {wej Daqmey yIHeD.:sen:nolink} "Go back three spaces."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: On {TKD p.172:src}, "I'm lost" is given as {jIHtaHbogh naDev vISovbe'.:sen:nolink} On {PK:src}, "I'm lost" is given in both regular and clipped Klingon versions, the latter of which is {DaqwIj Sovbe'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, this is a command rather than a question. It literally means, "Identify the place where you live!"[1]
An acceptable way to phrase this demand as a question is {nuq DaDab?:sen:nolink}[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {jej; Daqtagh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the beverage only. For the dried-up mixture used to brew tea, see {Qenvob:n}.
Darjeeling is a type of tea.
{Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, "cup and saucer" is translated as {Dargh HIvje' jengva' je:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is never followed by the locative suffix {-Daq:n:suff}. ({TKD 3.3.5:src})
▶ {qatlh Dat DI tu'lu', tlhIngan?:sen:nolink} "Why is there rubble everywhere, Klingon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: sway (aircraft moves to the side without yawing)
It is unknown if this has meaning outside of the context of aircraft attitude descriptions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a title for a warrior who has attained legendary status in life.
[1] {DS9 - Blood Oath:src}, [2] {A Good Day to Die:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird characterized by erratic, unpredictable behavior
This bird is similar to a {Da'vI':n}.
This is a reference to Donald Duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird characterized by erratic, unpredictable behavior
This is a reference to Daffy Duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the second highest rank of {QaS:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being surrounded. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a duty station on a ship, not to something worn on the head (which would be {mIv:n}).

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: For Klingons, this is preferred to {baQ:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your face looks like a collapsed star!

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {no' Hol:n} expression used by a captain upon taking command of a ship.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {DenIbya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This creature is also called {DenIbya' Qatlh:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A Denebian is also called a {DenIbya'ngan:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the Terran retelling of {Hamlet:src}, the titular character is the prince of this country on Earth.

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of using language (see {-pu':n:suff}) or beings incapable of using language (see {-mey:n:suff}).

table.name: mem
table.column: yaw (aircraft nose points left or right)
It is unknown if this word has meaning outside the context of aircraft attitude.
The rud"der" controls the yaw on an airplane.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for both the body part and the handle of a {nevDagh:n}. Note that the suffix {-Du':n} is used even with the latter meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you're looking for someone named "Data", see {qoqyoq:n:hyp}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Knowledge of useful information may be unfortunate.

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of the author of this program and the compiler of its lexicon.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qatlh Dat DI tu'lu', tlhIngan?:sen:nolink} "Why is there rubble everywhere, Klingon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In slang, "(first) dibs" means the right to something.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix turns a cardinal number into an ordinal number. For example, {wa'DIch:n:num} "first" from {wa':n:num} "one", {cha'DIch:n:1,num} "second" from {cha':n:num} "two", and so on. Ordinal numbers follow the noun to which they apply.

table.name: mem
table.column: Its leaf ({DIghna' por:n:nolink}) is fried (see {mIQ:v}) by experienced cooks.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is deep-fried (see {mIQ:v}) and eaten.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: slide sword blade along opponent's blade

table.name: mem
table.column: use a pigment stick, paint with pigment stick

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist as a word, but appears as a component of {bo'DIj:n} and {ghIpDIj:v}. Its homophony to {DIj:v:1} (def'n 1) suggests that it describes two parties pitted against one another.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not defined as such in canon, but appears in the example from {TKD p.171:src}, the exact grammar of which is not clear. This entry is here for ease of reference only.
▶ {Dochvetlh DIlmeH Huch 'ar DaneH?:sen} "How much do you want for that?"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traded commodity which, like {qevaS:n}, is a type of gemstone.

table.name: mem
table.column: open entryway (to corridor, tunnel, conduit, Jeffries tube, branch of sewer)
This is the open entryway of any enclosed space longer than wide in which people might find themselves. If there is a door that closes, this is not a {DIn:n:nolink}. It is merely a {lojmIt:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word takes the suffix {-Du':n:suff} when it refers to skin still on the body, and {-mey:n:suff} otherwise.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a drum made with animal skin stretched over a cylinder, usually over only one end. If skin is stretched over both ends of a drum, it is an {'o'lav:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: For "years ago" and "years from now", see {ben:n:1} and {nem:n}, respectively.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used to refer to "the Federation", a shortened form of "the United Federation of Planets" ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}).
Coincidentally or not, this words sounds similar to {DI vI':n:nolink} "accumulated debris".
The real reason {DIvI':n:nolink} and {DI vI':n:nolink} sound alike is because of the backfitting of {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {Qe':n} with a sign that says {moD Soj:sen:nolink}.[1, p.102]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not canonical but is apparently widely known.

table.name: mem
table.column: How much do you want for that?

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the separator used in specifying a set of coordinates, and not to a specific coordinate point or location (for which see {Quv:n}.)
▶ {He wej pagh Soch DoD cha':sen:nolink} "course 3-0-7-mark-2" ▶ {He pagh-pagh-pagh-DoD-cha' yInab!:sen:nolink} "Plot course zero-zero-zero, mark two."

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom {Dogh; tIghla' rur}.[2, p.127]

table.name: mem
table.column: This consists of the words for "silly" and "defeat".

table.name: mem
table.column: back away from, back off, get away from

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is defined in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.
Based on the example of {qawmoH:v}, the subject of {DoHmoH:v:nolink} does the driving back, {-vaD:n} marks that which is driven back, and the object is the thing or location it is driven back from.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "entity" in {TKD:src} and as "whole" in {TKW:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Dop:n:nolink} is used to indicate one face of a playing card.
▶ {DopDaq qul yIchenmoH QobDI' ghu'.:sen}[2] ▶ {'echletHom Dopvam yIcha':sen:nolink} "card must be turned this side up"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Set fire on the side when there is danger.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb also covers colors which would be called "brown". To differentiate a brown object from another object which could also be described using {Doq:v:nolink}, a phrase such as {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen} is used.[2]

All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v:nolink} and {SuD:v:1}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

table.name: mem
table.column: The expressions {Doq bIQtIq:sen:nolink} ("the river is red") and {Doq bIQtIq bIQ:sen:nolink} ("the river water is red") can be traced back to an old drinking song commemorating the slaying of {molor:n:name} by {qeylIS:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: to be a particular shade of brown
A kradge has brown lips. This expression is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).

table.name: mem
table.column: To be more specific about the shade of brown, a comparison is used. For example, one might say {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} (kradge lips are a particular shade of brown).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject of this verb is a period or unit of time, such as a month. It should not be an event the ending of which one has some control over (for which see {van:v:2}, {ghang:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression, which literally means to lose or misplace a target, means "to digress". {DoS vIchIl:sen:nolink} means "I digress", and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is generally crafted from bone.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear if {tlhuch:v} "exhaust" means to "tire someone out".

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {TKD p.20:src}, it's likely that {Do':n:archaic,hyp,nolink} is an archaic word for the modern {Duj:n:2}. This conjecture is supported by {'ejDo':n} and {Delaq Do':excl}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is essentially the verb {Do'Ha':v} as a standalone sentence.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the thing which is improved.
This verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature, such as in status, skill, understanding, etc. For improvement in a more concrete sense, see {rach:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: If it's in your way, knock it down.

table.name: mem
table.column: As a joke, this is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {yIntaHvIS qIrq DuHbe' roj.:sen:nolink} "There will be no peace as long as Kirk lives." ({Star Trek V:src} notes, not actually in the film)

table.name: mem
table.column: It is grammatically correct to treat this word as singular (a bundle of instincts) or plural (individual instincts).[2, p.27]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word can refer to any vehicle, not just spaceships, by specifying the environment in which the vehicle travels. See {puH Duj:n}, {muD Duj:n}, {bIQ Duj:n}.
Some special terminology is used for the parts of a {Duj:n:2,nolink}. The section towards its {tlhop:n} is called its {'et:n}, while the section towards its {'em:n} is called its {'o':n}. To refer to a ship's dorsal, ventral, port, and starboard areas, see {Dung:n}, {bIng:n}, {poS:n}, and {nIH:n}, respectively.
For verbs related to ship movement, see under {'or:v}.
Known classes of Klingon ships include {neghvar:n}, {vorcha':n}, {qItI'nga':n}, {qISa'ruj:n}, and {toQDuj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: DujDaj HubtaHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.
To die defending his ship is the hope of every Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is nothing shameful in falling before a superior enemy.

table.name: mem
table.column: {Dujmey law' DachIjpu':sen:nolink} "You have navigated many ships", i.e., "You are experienced".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {ta'mey Dun, bommey Dun.:sen} ▶ {qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.:sen:nolink} "You would be the greatest warrior in the galaxy." ({Star Trek V:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: See {'aqroS:n:1} and {yor:n} for the top parts of an object. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a way to "dupe" your enemies.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bowl used for eating {chatlh:n:1}, which a diner pours into the {Duq:n:nolink} from a {maHpIn:n}.[1, p.99]
Norm Duke is the name of a successful American professional bowler. Also, "duckpin bowling" is a variation of "ten-pin bowling" using a smaller ball.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is said of good music or food.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to refer to the spikes attached to {pogh:n}, {ghanjaq:n}, {'alngegh:n}, and so on.
For a stand-alone spike such as a stake, see {wIl:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to refer to the little spikes found on the {Daqtagh:n}.[1, p.61]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a food item. It never uses any plural suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used for launching a {peng:n}.
The distinction between a {DuS:n:nolink} and a {chetvI':n} has to do with how the projectile is loaded.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the most general word for a place of learning.[1]
It's probably just a coincidence that this word looks like it's formed from {Du-:v} and {SaQ:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to fruits or vegetables that come from a farm, as opposed to {naH tlhab:n}.[1, p.89]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extra space right after {mIv:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This may have bones. In some regional dialects, {ghab:n:nolink} is not applied to meat lacking bones, but rather, {ghab tun:n} is used instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: meat from midsection of animal, no bones

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the sound made when gargling.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "he/she wants the wind to respect him/her".
▶ {muvuvpu' SuS vIneH.:sen:nolink} "I acted like a fool." ▶ {bImaw''a'? Duvuv SuS DaneH'a'?:sen:nolink} "What's with you? Are you an idiot?"

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be used both to indicate ownership over an object (see {yer ghajwI' chaw':n}) and possession of a more abstract nature (see {pIch:n} and {quv:n}).

▶ {pIch vIghajbe'.:sen} "It's not my fault."[1] ▶ {Hov ghajbe'bogh ram rur pegh ghajbe'bogh jaj.:sen}[2] ▶ {quv lughaj Archer HoD beqDaj je. lengtaH 'e' yIchaw'.:sen:nolink} "Captain Archer and his crew are honorable people. Let them continue on their way."[3] ▶ {Duj ghajchugh pagh, beylI'vo' 'oH Daje' net chaw'.:sen:nolink} "If (the ship is) unowned, you may buy it from the Bank."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: Jealousy is also expressed by the idiom {SuD veqlargh mInDu':sen}.
The word {ghal:v:nolink} was mistakenly used as a noun meaning "envoy" in the Dramatis Personae of the {paq'batlh:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the animal version of {ghIv:n}.
There is a slang word "gam" in English which means "leg".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to something one copies or refers to in making things.

table.name: mem
table.column: end prematurely (an event, voyage, battle, play, opera, story, song, etc.)

The subject of this verb is the person causing an event to prematurely end. The object is the event that is ended. If the ending of the event was not premature, use {van:v:2} instead. To describe the ending of a period of time, use {Dor:v:2} instead.
Quite often, the hitting of a "gong" brings an event to a premature end.
▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is also used for "support" in the monetary sense.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of a Klingon Chancellor. He is portrayed by the actor {rabe'rIt 'o'raylIy:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is avoided in {voSpegh Sep:n}, where {'IghvaH chej chatlh:n} is used instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: insecure one, one full of self-doubt
This is a dialectical word used in {voSpegh Sep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not known only through {bIQ ghaywI' pa':n} and the example below from {Klingon Monopoly:src}.
{jorwI'mey ghaymo' qarDaSnganpu', Hegh SuvwI'pu'lI' law' 'ej rIQ SuvwI'pu'lI' law'.:sen:nolink} "Suffer major losses after Cardassian bombing campaign."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a condiment which is often used to bring out the flavor in {qagh:n} or {raHta':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: {gheb rIl:sen:nolink} is a reference to the horn of Gabriel.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is used to ask a question, whereas {tlhob:v} is used for making a request.[2]
The object of this verb is the question asked.

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist as a word, but appears as a component of {nenghep:n} and {peHghep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb expresses the idea of bringing thoughts together into a reasonably coherent form so that they can be expressed to someone else. It differs from {qon:v} in that {gher:v:nolink} suggests that information is merely being passed along.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: assume duties of, take on responsibilities of

▶ {DaH yaS wa'DIch vIgheS} "I now take my place as first officer", or literally, "Now I assume the responsibilities of first officer"[1, p.182] ▶ {juDev 'ej Dujvam ra'wI' DagheS 'e' vItlhob} "I ask you to lead us as commander of this ship", or literally, "I request that you lead us and that you assume the duties of commander of this ship"[1, p.184]

table.name: mem
table.column: No deception is implied by the use of this word. It simply indicates role-playing.

table.name: mem
table.column: No deception is implied by the use of this word. It simply indicates role-playing.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a warrior who singlehandedly defeated an invading force.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: This region contains the city of {ruq'e'vet:n}. It is named after {ghevchoq:n:name}.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {jeD; ghevI' rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", cricket (the sport) is translated as {ghew:n:nolink}. Specifically, "Cricket, please." was translated as {DaH ghew yIQuj.:sen:nolink}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: An example of Klingon opera is "Aktu and Mellota" (see {'aqtu':n:name} and {mellota':n:name}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {ghe'naQ:n} following the traditional form preferred by purists.

table.name: mem
table.column: Gre'thor, netherworld (where spirits of dishonored go)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is similar to the Terran expression, "when pigs fly".
▶ {jIjegh ghe'torvo' narghDI' qa'pu'.:sen:nolink} "I will surrender when spirits escape from Gre'thor." (That is, "I will never surrender.")

table.name: mem
table.column: You belong in a black hole in the netherworld!

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {boch; ghIch rur}.[2, p.133]
There is also a regional word {ley':n} which means "nose".

table.name: mem
table.column: If you shine my nose, I will give you your nose.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, this word is used in addition to {yepHa':v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: May your enemies run with fear.
This sentence is archaic. It is ungrammatical in modern standard Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a small, irritating insect with no sting, which makes a slight buzzing sound. There is a Klingon idiom, {ram; ghIlab ghew rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Pay no heed to glob flies.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device which dissipates heat.
Some people believe this to be a mistake for {tlhuchwI':n:nolink} (see {tlhuch:v}). However, {tuj ghImwI':n} actually makes sense for a mechanism that dissipates heat.

table.name: mem
table.column: Plymouth Gin is produced by The Black Friars Distillery, formerly a Dominican monastery in Plymouth, England.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is described in the glossary to {A Burning House:src} as a game involving tokens and wagers.

table.name: mem
table.column: trusted adviser of a Klingon house
In {TNG - Firstborn:src}, K'mtar is the gin'tak to the House of Mogh.[1] In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, it is claimed that this word and {ghIntaq:n:1} are in fact the same word.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that this is a verb, not a noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that "then" in the sense of "at that time" is {ngugh:adv}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: When descending, you need to drop your landing "gear".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a small animal, apparently not a very vicious one, though one with perhaps a predilection for trying to sound fiercer than it actually is.

table.name: mem

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column: {ghItlh vIghItlhta'bogh DalaD'a'?:sen:nolink} "Will you read my manuscript?"[1, p.172]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used to indicate the making of markings on a surface. It applies not just to writing, but to any kind of marking. To "write" in this sense refers to the physical act of writing, and not to the creation of compositions, for which {qon:v} is used instead.[2; 3] Another verb, {gher:v}, is used for the compilation of lists and the like.[4]
This is defined in {TKD:src} as "write". In {KGT:src}, it was clarified that this meant "engrave, incise, mark (upon)", that is, the phyiscal act of making marks on a surface.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, {ghItlhwI':n:nolink} is used for "pen" and {ghojmoH ghItlhwI':n:nolink} is used for "pencil".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the person equivalent of {gham:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {wov; ghI'boj Sech rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {meyrI'Daq 'oHtaH gho'e':sen:nolink} "The circle is in the square."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: It is probably significant that this word is homophonous with the verb for doing battle or waging war ({ghob:v}).[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: fight, battle, do battle, wage war

This verb refers to a concrete fight. For the concept of making war, see {Qoj:v}.
It is probably significant that this word is homophonous with the word for ethics or virtue ({ghob:n}).[2]
In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a famous statue.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is one of the items traditionally displayed on a {nuH bey':n}. It is a gutting device used in balance with a shield.[1]
The spelling of this word is not confirmed, and it is only spoken in {KCD:src}. It may be {Qob'etlh:n:nolink} or {ghab'etlh:n:nolink} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the negative answer to a yes/no question (see {-'a':v}). For an exclamation indicating refusal and so on, see {Qo':excl}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Kahless prophesied he would return there.

table.name: mem
table.column: Some people have taken to referring to mobile phones using {ghogh HablI' qenglu'bogh:n:nolink}. Context should make it clear if {ghogh HablI':n:nolink} refers to a mobile device.

table.name: mem
table.column: The idiom {jop 'ej way':sen:idiom} expresses a similar idea.[2]

table.name: mem

table.column: ▶ {ngIq gholvo' wa'maH QaS yItlhap.:sen:nolink} "Collect 10 forces from every player."[2]

table.column: This verb can be used with or without an object.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is described as a vegetable usually served diced.

table.name: mem
table.column: The parts of a hand include its {toch:n} "palm", {chap:n} "back (of hand)", and {nItlh:n} "finger(s)" (including the thumb). The hand is attached to the {DeS:n:1} "arm" through the {yeb:n} "wrist".
Something you "grope" with. The reverse of this is {pogh:n}.
▶ {ghopDu'wIjDaq yInmeyraj vIlaj} "I accept your lives into my hands"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "spy" in {TKD:src} and as "spy on" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem

table.column: When will the water be hot?

table.name: mem
table.column: approach, go away from, proceed, come, follow (a course)
The way to use {ghoS:v:nolink} and other verbs of movement are described in {HQ 7.4:src}[2]. See {jaH:v} for details.

mem

This is based on a joke English spelling for "fish".

table.name: mem
table.column: A single personnel file would presumably be a {ghot ta:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Someone going at sublight speed really needs to "step on" it.

table.name: mem
table.column: See also the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v} for indicating preparation or readiness.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.

table.name: mem
table.column: The example makes clear that this word refers to temperature, and not to perception, emotion, or character.
▶ {ghun 'Iw HIq, rap boqrat chej.} "The bokrat liver is as warm as the bloodwine."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom {ghung; qagh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The word {ghurmoH} appears on {SkyBox 14:src} (see {nISwI' beH:n}).[2]
MO confirmed at {Saarbrucken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that {ghur:v:nolink} is intransitive.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object of this verb is the thing to be launched, usually torpedoes. If the object is not specified either explicitly or by context, it is assumed to be torpedoes. Besides torpedoes, this verb can be used for rockets, missiles, energy beams, or anything else which goes from one point to another. It is also used to describe the action of pulling back the elastic band of a slingshot, or the lowering of a spear to a horizontal position to attack (see {ghuS:v:2} (def'n 2)). This verb never takes the suffix {-rup:v}. ({TKD 4.2.2:src})
See also the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v} for indicating preparation or readiness.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can be used to describe the readying of any kind of projectile weapon, such as pulling back the elastic band of a slingshot. On a starship, it's used almost exclusively to refer to torpedoes (see {ghuS:v:1} (def'n 1)).[1, p.64]

table.name: mem
table.column: She is the actress who plays {be'etor:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your mother has a smooth forehead!

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of stone indigenous to {Qo'noS:n} which is often used in the contruction of statuary.

table.name: mem

table.column: Only fools laugh while warriors die.

table.column:
The object is the thing being soaked or drenched.
{HaH'egh:v:nolink} is used to refer to drinking a great deal, or bathing.

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {jIH:n:2} refers to the device, while {HaSta:n:nolink} refers to the visual information displayed on it. Also contrast this with {wIy:n}, which can also be displayed on a {jIH:n:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In slang, stolen goods are said to be "hot".

table.name: mem
table.column: To challenge someone to a duel, say {qablIj HI'ang:sen:nolink}. To accept such a challenge, say {vISo'be':sen:nolink}.[2, p.68]

table.name: mem
table.column: For different ways in which meat may be prepared, see {wamwI' Ha'DIbaH:n}, {voDleH Ha'DIbaH:n}, and {qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n}.

table.column: Do not kill an animal unless you intend to eat it.

table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran food.

table.name: mem
table.column: In ancient times, this supported a sword. Now it is symbolic of one's {tuq:v}.

▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The expression {Ha'qujlIj nge':sen:nolink} "take away your sash" means "wound your pride".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can only refer to a physical path, and not to a spiritual or metaphorical path. "The Klingon Way", for example, is {tlhIngan tIgh:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column: The fact that {yIn:v} can be used transitively suggests that {Hegh:v:nolink} can be too.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: A fool's only achievement is death.

table.name: mem
table.column: This may also be written as {Heghba':n:nolink}.
It is written {Heghba':n:nolink} in the novel "Sarek".

table.name: mem
table.column: When a warrior dies, his spirit escapes.

table.name: mem
table.column: Death is an experience best shared.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is a good day to die.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, {bIQ'a' HeH:n} is used to translate "beach".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an admirable trait and does not carry connotations of arrogance, for which see {nguq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons are a proud race, and we intend to go on being proud.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a character from a Shakespeare play.

table.name: mem
table.column: finger (holes, strings of instrument) to vary sound

This word is applied to {SuSDeq:n} and {HurDagh:n}.
See under {nItlh:n} for the verbs associated with each of the fingers.

table.name: mem
table.column: {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

table.column: R. Hess was a famous war criminal.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {tam; Hew rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: {HIj:v:nolink} is used for transporting goods, whereas it seems that {lup:v} is used for transporting people.
▶ {yIHmey DaHIj'a'? ghobe', yIHmey vIHIjbe'.} "Are you transporting tribbles? No. I'm not transporting tribbles."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the positive answer to a yes/no question (see {-'a':v}). For an exclamation indicating compliance and so on, see {lu':excl}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a canonical Klingon word, but is a joke word coined by {HoD Qanqor:n:name,nolink} which is understood by the {qolqoS:n} of the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}. It is a reference to a ritual observed and food eaten during the Passover Seder.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the clothing worn in battle.
In English slang, "hip" means fashionable in the context of clothing.

table.name: mem
table.column: To find ale, go into a bar.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is known as a tourist drink.

table.name: mem
table.column: A ship cloaks in order to attack.

table.name: mem
table.column: If the following noun is explicitly plural, it means "all the X's", taken collectively. If the noun is not explicitly plural, then it means "each X", considered individually.[2]

▶ {Hoch tlhInganpu':sen:nolink} "all Klingons"[2] ▶ {Hoch paqmey:sen:nolink} "all the books"[2] ▶ {Hoch 'ebmey tIjon.:sen} "Capture all opportunities" (and not "each opportunity") ▶ {wo' toy'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.:sen} "To die while serving the Empire is the hope of every Klingon" (i.e., every Klingon, individually)

table.name: mem
table.column: end, last item in a list

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an emphatic alternative for {reH:adv}.
{Hochlogh no' yIquvmoH.:sen:nolink} "Always honor your ancestors", literally, "All times honor your ancestors".

table.name: mem
table.column: Pity the warrior who slays all his foes.

This is a famous line from the poem {lu qeng:n:name,nolink} by G'trok. The idiomatic expression {Hoch jaghpu'Daj HoHpu':sen:nolink} "He/she has killed all his/her enemies" means that a person leads a meaningless, empty life, one lacking any challenge.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression, which is based on the homophony of the words {nuH:n:1} (def'n1) and {nuH:n:2} (def'n 2), means "to consider every possibility" or "to consider every option".
▶ {Hoch nuH yIqel!:sen:nolink} "Consider every possibility!" ▶ {Hoch nuH Daqel'a'?:sen:nolink} "Did you consider every option?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Eat everything or you will die without honor.
This is roughly like saying, "Eat, eat!"
QI'lop, Eat everything or you will die without honour.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is short for {romuluSngan Sambogh 'ej HoHbogh nejwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is simply the verb {HoH:v} with the suffix {-'egh:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, names of languages are formed by attaching {Hol:n:nolink} to an identifier for the language. For example, "Klingon" (the language) is {tlhIngan Hol:n}, and {tlhIngan:n} by itself does not refer to the language, but to a person or people.
The identifier is usually a country, region, or political unit of some kind. For example, Federation Standard (i.e., "English") is {DIvI' Hol:n}. {tlhIngan Hol:n:nolink} is actually a shortened form of {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also the name of the journal of the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: weakling, runt, scrawny one, skinny one

table.name: mem
table.column: Due to the homophony with {Hom:2:n} (def'n 2), to point one's second toe at someone (typically an opponent or an enemy), while the other toes point downwards, is considered an insulting gesture. It signifies that one considers the other person to be weak.
{jaghwI'Daq jIHom.:sen:nolink} "I claim my enemy is unworthy or weak."

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vIHon.:sen:nolink} "I doubt that you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is used in the same way as {Sum:v} (it involves the concept of deixis).[2]
In Klingon, "deep space" is called {logh Hop:n}, literally, "far space".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This seems to be composed from {Hoq:n} and an unknown element {ra':n:hyp,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be honored falsely, be falsely honorable

Deception is implied by the use of this verb.
This word is used in places where {quv:v} might be used, but when the honor was discovered to be illegitimate. For exampe, a {Duy quv:n:nolink} who turns out to be a spy would be called a {Duy HoQ:n:nolink}.
It differs from {quvHa':v} in that it indicates that one has demanded respect which is unearned or undeserved. A warrior who shows cowardice in battle is a {SuvwI' quvHa':n:nolink}. One who hides his cowardice, is awarded for valor (i.e., becomes known as a {SuvwI' quv:n:nolink}), and is subsequently discovered to be a fraud, is a {SuvwI' HoQ:n:nolink}.
Do not use this word lightly as it has very bad connotations in Klingon society.
be honoured falsely, be falsely honourable

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a device which changes energy from one form to another.

table.name: mem
table.column: You are a total waste of good energy!

table.name: mem
table.column: {pIraqSIS:n} is an important Klingon energy facility.
▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice."

table.name: mem
table.column: It's not clear if this word is grammatically singular or plural. One energy being is a {HoS Dep:n:nolink} (see {HoS:n}, {Dep:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The term {HoS Hal:n:nolink} (with a space) has also appeared in canon. See the example under {nISwI' beH:n}.

▶ {HoSHal ghajchugh vay', mI' naghmey tIronmoH. wa'maHlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey; chen qav'ap. ghajwI'vaD qav'ap yIDIl.:sen:nolink} "If [energy source is] owned, throw dice and pay owner a total ten times amount shown."

table.name: mem
table.column: Hov ghajbe'bogh ram rur pegh ghajbe'bogh jaj.
A day without secrets is like a night wihout stars.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a popular television series.

table.name: mem
table.column: It really ought to be {Hov leng cham:n:nolink}, but canon is canon.

table.column: ▶ {tera' poH jaj wa', jar wa', jaj loSDIch, DIS wa'-Hut-Hut-chorgh. HovpoHvetlh latlh nab yIHutlh.:sen:nolink} "Save this Stardate: Sunday, January 4, 1998"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word follows the grammatical rules appropriate to its literal meaning (see {Ho':n:1} (def'n 1)). It takes the plural suffix {-Du':n:suff} and possessive suffixes such as {-wIj:n:suff}, even when it refers to a person or people.[1, p.152]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that a human ({Human:n:nolink}) is a member of the indigenous sentient species of Earth ({tera':n:place}), whereas Terran ({tera'ngan:n}) refers to any inhabitant of the planet.

table.column: This animal is known for its speed.
{nom leng Hun nom lengqu' lut:sen:nolink} "Stories travel faster than a Khrun"[2]

table.column: ▶ {Hung buv rav; patlh Hut:sen:nolink} "Classified Level 9 and Above"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the general term for a musical instrument with strings ({SIrgh:n}), which one may either pluck ({pang:v}) or strum ({yach:v:2}). To vary the sound, one "fingers" ({Heng:v}) the strings (touch them at different points while plucking or strumming).
Types of {HurDagh:n:nolink} include the {Supghew:n} (small), the {leSpal:n} (medium), and the {tIngDagh:n} (large).

table.name: mem
table.column: In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is described as a fruit grown on Klingon farms.

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column: too many people or things in a place at once
This term is used as a play on words, substituting for the curse {Qu'vatlh:excl} in situations where it is appropriate.
This word was disclosed during a congested drive on Interstate 95.

table.column: This is a reference to the industrial rock band "Nine Inch Nails".

table.name: mem
table.column: lack, be without, to not have

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to throw or hurl something like a projectile.[1, p.91]

table.name: mem
table.column: To defeat the enemy, be ready to fight alone.

table.name: mem
table.column: May the bile of the vanquished fill your hands.

table.name: mem
table.column: If the verb prefix indicates an object, then the subject is going to a destination associated with the object, which may be marked with {-Daq:n}. If the verb prefix indicates no object, then the destination is unspecified. In that case, a noun marked with {-Daq:n:nolink} indicates the location where the "going" is taking place.[2]

▶ {bIQtIqDaq jIjaH.:sen:nolink} "I go in the river." This means: I'm moving along in the river, traveling in the river.[2] ▶ {bIQtIq vIjaH.:sen:nolink} or {bIQtIqDaq vIjaH.:sen:nolink} (the {-Daq:n:nolink} is optional) This means: I'm moving along to the river, traveling to the river.[2] ▶ {bIghHa' yIjaH:sen:nolink} "Go to jail"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Klingon day goes from dawn to dawn. For the part of a day during which there is daylight, see {pem:n} (the opposite of which is night, {ram:n}).
The parts of a {jaj:n:nolink} are: {pem:n} "daytime", {jajlo':n} "dawn", {po:n} "morning", {pemjep:n} "midday", {DungluQ:n} "noon", {pov:n} "afternoon", {ram:n} "night", {ramjep:n:1} "midnight".
For "days ago" and "days from now", see {Hu':n} and {leS:n}, respectively.

table.name: mem
table.column: A noisy animal (not a bird) known for making a ruckus at dawn, like a Terran rooster.

table.name: mem
table.column: While both {DaHjaj:n} and {jajvam:n:nolink} mean "today", they are not quite interchangeable.[2] See under {DaHjaj:n} for details.

table.name: mem

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the name of the {HoD:n} of the {'entepray':n:name} during the time of {puq poH veb:n}.
In Klingon, titles generally go after the name, so "Captain Jean-Luc Picard" would be {janluq pIqarD HoD:n:nolink}. Note that {pIqarD:n:nolink} does not follow proper Klingon phonology, since it is an alien name.

table.name: mem
table.column:
A typical object of this verb is that which is spoken, which might be a language or lecture. The listener is the indirect object and is marked with {-vaD:n}.[3; 4]
The "prefix trick" may be used with this verb: if the verb prefix indicates a first- or second-person object, that person is the indirect object, that is, the person to whom the subject is speaking.[3]
The verb {jatlh:v:nolink} is also used when giving a direct quotation, in which case the verb prefix indicating no object is used. The quotation may come before or after the sentence with {jatlh:v:nolink}.[3]
This verb and {ja':v} are the only known Klingon "verbs of speech".[4]

In {TKD:src}, this is defined in the K-E word list as "say", and listed in the E-K word list under "speak". In {TKDA:src}, it is defined in both word lists as "say".
In the {msn:src} newsgroup message, it says that the verb prefix indicating no object is used for a direct quotation if the speaker is first or second person.[3] It's left unclear if {lu-:v:pref} should be used if the speakers are third-person and plural.

▶ {tlhIngan Hol vIjatlhlaHbe'.:sen}[1] ▶ {bIjatlh 'e' yImev!:sen}[1] ▶ {SoQ Dajatlh.:sen:nolink} "You deliver an address", "You make a speech."[3] ▶ {qajatlh.:sen:nolink} "I speak to you."[3] ▶ {tlhIngan jIH jatlh.:sen:nolink} or {jatlh tlhIngan jIH.:sen:nolink} "He/she says, 'I am a Klingon'."[3] ▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh.:sen:nolink} "You speak Klingon."[3] ▶ {tlhIngan Hol bIjatlh.:sen:nolink} "You say, 'Klingon language'."[3] ▶ {SoHvaD pagh vIjatlh, Human.:sen:nolink} "I have nothing to say to you, human."[5]

The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2,nolink}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.column: When {je:adv:nolink} follows a verb, it means "also, too". {qaleghpu' je:sen:nolink} means "I also saw you, I saw you too", and as in English, its meaning is ambiguous. (It could mean "I and others saw you" or "I saw you and others".)[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
This is the general verb for measurement. The subject of this verb is taking the measurement of the object.[2]
To indicate the length, width, and depth of an object, see {'aD:v}, {juch:v}, and {Saw':v}, respectively. For objects which are much longer or taller than they are wide, use {'ab:v} instead of {'aD:v}. The Klingon unit of linear measure is the {'uj:n}.
Distances can be described using {chuq:n}, {Sum:v}, and {Hop:v}. For large distances, use {qelI'qam:n}; for even larger (e.g., interstellar) distances, use {loghqam:n}.
To express a volume, use {muq:v} (see also {tIn:v}, {mach:v}). See {tlho'ren:n} for a unit of volume.
To express a weight (mass), use {ngI':v} (see also {tIS:v}, {'ugh:v}). See {cheb:n} for a unit of weight or mass.

table.name: mem
table.column: In other words, "upload" (or possibly "download", depending on context).

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {law':v:nolink} is used in comparative constructions. See {... X law' ... X puS:sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This construction is used to form comparatives and superlatives. The two things being compared go into the two slots. To form the superlative, {Hoch:n} is used in the second slot.[1]
Other antonym pairs may be substituted in place of {law':v} and {puS:v} as a form of word play.[2]
To say that something is not more {X:sen:nolink} than something else, {law'be':v:nolink} and {puSbe':v:nolink} are used instead of {law':v:nolink} and {puS:v:nolink}. To say that something is as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {law':v:nolink} is used with {law':v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered positive), or {puS:v:nolink} is used with {puS:v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered negative), or {law':v:nolink} is used with {rap:v} or {nIb:v} (the latter of which implies the two things being compared are exactly the same in some way). It is also possible to use {puS:v:1,nolink} with {rap:v} or {nIb:v}, but that carries a connotation of disparagement. To say that something is not as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {pIm:v} is used in place of the second verb in the pair.[3]
To say that two things have the same amount of some quality, it's also possible to use {rap:v} or {nIb:v} without a {law':v:nolink}/{puS:v:1,nolink} construction. (See those verbs for details.)
The above constructions are typically used only to compare similar things. To form similes, which compare things which are unlike, use {rur:v} instead. When the above constructions are used to compare unlike things, they generally reference well-known similes.

table.column: The Klingon sentence on {SkyBox 13:src} seems to have dropped some words, since it is ungrammatical.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Klingon compass has three points, rather than four: {chan:n} (east), {'ev:n} (northwest), and {tIng:n} (southwest).
The areas around an object are its {Dung:n} (area above), {bIng:n} (area below), {retlh:n} (area beside), {tlhop:n} (front), and {'em:n} (behind). Something in an object's {retlh:n:nolink} can be on its {poS:n} (left) or its {nIH:n} (right). The area between two objects are their {joj:n} (area between).
In standard Klingon, locative nouns follow pronouns, e.g., {jIH tlhop:n:nolink} "in front of me". But in the dialect of the Sakrej region ({Sa'Qej Sep:n}), locative nouns take pronominal possessive suffixes, e.g., {tlhopwIj:n:nolink} "my area in front".[2] However, the directional nouns are an exception to this rule, and take possessive suffixes in every known dialect, e.g., {chanwIj:n:nolink} "east of me, to my east". If the full pronoun is used with a directional noun, the pronoun is emphasized, e.g., {jIH chan:n:nolink} "east of ME, to MY east".[4]
The points in between the three cardinal directions are {tIng chan:n:nolink}, {'ev chan:n:nolink}, and either {tIng 'ev:n:nolink} or {'ev tIng:n:nolink}. {chan:n:nolink} always comes second in such a compound.[3]

▶ {veng chanDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt east of the city." ▶ {chan vengDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city in the east." ▶ {veng chan yoSDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city's east (the eastern part of the city)." ▶ {'evmajDaq jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here." (Northwest is relative to the speaker's location.) ▶ {Daqvam 'ev jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here." (Northwest is relative to a location indicated by the speaker, for example a point on a map.)

table.name: mem
table.column: Sister of B'Etor and Duras. She is portrayed by the actress {barbara' ma'rIch:n:name}.

▶ {DuraS tuq tlhIngan yejquv patlh luDub 'e' reH lunIDtaH DuraS be'nI'pu' lurSa' be'etor je. ngoQvam luchavmeH ghawran maghpu' be'nI'pu'. woQ luSuqmeH jIjpu' chaH romuluSngan'e' je.:sen:nolink} "The sisters of the House of Duras, Lursa and B'Etor, are constantly seeking a higher standing for the House of Duras within the Klingon High Council. To this end, the sisters have acted against Gowron, going as far as to work with Romulan factions in order to gain power."[2]
