table.name: mem
table.column: This term has not been used in canon, but its meaning is inferred by analogy with {vatlh DIS poH:n}, etc. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an exclamation expressing satisfaction. For the verb (or adjective) meaning "to be good", see {QaQ:v}.
This word does not have the sense of "good" as used in a greeting, such as "good morning" or "good night". While there is an idiomatic expression in Klingon, {maj ram:sen:nolink}, which is used in a similar manner to "good night", it actually means something like "Good, (it is) night".[2]

In {TNK:src}, "Good morning" is given as {maj po:excl:nolink}, "Good afternoon" as {maj pov:excl:nolink}, and "Good evening" as {maj choS:excl:nolink}. In {DS9 - The Sword of Kahless:src}, Jadzia Dax and Kor said {maj ram:excl:nolink} to each other as she headed for bed.

table.name: mem
table.column: The first element of this word appears to be {maj:excl}. The second element may be related to {Qap:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of stick, rope, etc.), other end from {'er'In:n}

This can refer to either end of the rope, stick or whatever, but once you arbitrarily choose an end to call {megh'an:n:nolink}, the other end is called {'er'In:n}. Before you make this initial reference, either end can be called either {'er'In:n} or {megh'an:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for the kind of bridge that goes over a river, or connects two locations, is {QI:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In {TNK:src}, {DaH jImej:sen:nolink} is used for the Terran expression "goodbye". This literally means "I'm leaving now". A Klingon, of course, would just leave, without superfluous niceties such as declaring his or her intention to do so.
To express leaving a person or object (rather than a location), consider {lon:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A character in a famous Klingon opera.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what a Klingon would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "reason" in {TKD:src} and as "motive" in the word lists in {KGT:src}. It is also glossed as "logical thinking" (in the sense of "motive") in the body of {KGT:src} on p.154.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the portion of a trial or appeal where the evidence is heard.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {meqleH:n:nolink} is also called the {meqleH matlh:n:nolink}, to differentiate it from the similar sounding {betleH:n}.

table.column: In some dialects in this region, {letlh:n:2} refers only to the stairway connected to a ship, and {ngep'oS:n} refers to every other kind of stairway.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.29 and not in the glossary. It appears as {meqro'vaq:n:nolink} and not as {meqro'vaq Sep:n:nolink}, but it is described as a region (see {Sep:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: If there is no object, then the subject is the thing burning, e.g., {meQtaHbogh qachDaq Suv qoH neH.:sen}[2] If there is an object, then the subject is burning the object, e.g., {to'waQ meQ vutwI'.}[3] {meQ:v:nolink} can also be used adjectivally, e.g., {Ha'DIbaHmey meQ Sop 'e' tIv tera'nganpu'}.[4]
In the sentence from {CK:src}, {tIv:sen:nolink} should have been {lutIv:sen:nolink} since {tera'nganpu':n:nolink} is plural.

table.name: mem
table.column: Only a fool fights in a burning house.

table.name: mem
table.column: Loss of honor is implied by this verb, which is used as an adjective to describe one who has fallen from grace. It is not applicable to someone who would be described as {'utlh:n}, a word which implies a voluntary, honorable retirement.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be used for any sort of depiction, including drawings, photographs, cartoons, icons on 21st-century computers, and so on.
This is a combination of the Latin word for "thousand" with the Greek word for "word".

table.name: mem
table.column: Shakespeare's play {paghmo' tIn mIS:sen:nolink}, literally "The Confusion is Great Because of Nothing", has been translated into English as "Much Ado About Nothing" by the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}.
Based on the definition of {mIS:v}, this noun seems to mean "the mixing up of one thing with another", not "the state of perplexity".

table.name: mem
table.column: Based on the definition of {mIS:v}, this verb seems to mean "to mix one thing up with another", not "to cause someone to become perplexed".

table.name: mem
table.column: name of sculptor who made Blood Oath Circles

table.name: mem
table.column:
In {TNK:src}, {mIv:n:1,nolink} is used for "hat".
See {mIvDaq pogh cha':sen} for an idiom involving {mIv:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: a matter has been postponed or rescheduled

This expression literally means "to display a glove on one's helmet", and is used to convey the idea that a matter has been postponed or rescheduled. The phrase takes a number of forms, as appropriate to the parties to the commitment. For example, {mIvwIjDaq poghlIj vIcha':sen:nolink} "I display your glove on my helmet" implies that the postponed matter is between the speaker and the addressee.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {bargh:n} made of metal.

table.name: mem
table.column: fully dressed (as for a ceremonial affair)
Note that this idiom does not follow proper grammar, in that normally {je:conj} would be at the end.
{mIv je DaS tuQ ra'wI'.:sen:nolink} "The commander is in full dress uniform."

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremonial headpiece worn by some emperors.

table.name: mem
table.column: procedure, process, step, stage (in a process)

table.name: mem
table.column:
Number-forming elements include {maH:n:1,num}, {vatlh:n:num}, {SaD:n:num} ({SanID:n:num}), {netlh:n:num}, {bIp:n:num}, {'uy':n:num}.
When a number is used for numbering (labeling), as opposed to counting, it follows the noun. Ordinal numbers are formed with {-DIch:n:num,suff}. Repetitions are formed with {-logh:n:num,suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: dance, run in place, do calisthenics

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {mI' naghmey:n:nolink} refers to the playing dice. The verb {ron:v} is used for the action of throwing or rolling the dice.

▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice." ▶ {HoSHal ghajchugh vay', mI' naghmey tIronmoH. wa'maHlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey; chen qav'ap. ghajwI'vaD qav'ap yIDIl.:sen:nolink} "If [energy source is] owned, throw dice and pay owner a total ten times amount shown."

There is an idiom, {mIgh; molor rur}.

table.column: A reference to the Mona Lisa. This word is defined in {KGT:src} as "smile, grin, sneer".[1] It is explained that it can also mean "snarl" and "smirk" in a message on the msn newsgroup.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A parry where you thrust a sword or other edged weapon behind your neck in order to block an attack from the rear.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to signal the start of a duel.[1, p.68]
It is also used for beating {'In:n} (compare to {tlhaw':v} and {weq:v}).[1, p.75]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is also used to refer to the spiked pommel at end of a {Daqtagh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be usual, be standard, be normal

In {TKD:src}, this is defined only as "be usual".[1] In {SkyBox 14:src}, {nISwI' HIch motlh:n:nolink} is translated as "standard hand held disruptor".[2] In the {BoP:src} poster, {qughDo motlh:n:nolink} is translated as "normal cruising speed".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Today was a good day to die."
This exclamation is archaic. It was spoken by Kahless to Lukara. The modern equivalent is {Heghlu'meH QaQ jajvam.:sen}
today was a good day to die

table.name: mem
table.column: The meaning and use of this slang word are explained on {KGT p.154:src}.
▶ {jaghpu' mo' wIyajnIS.} "We must understand the enemies' motive."[1, p.154]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was defined in {TKD:src} as "present". The definition "perform (music)" was added in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for weather, meaning the state of the atmosphere, is the same word as for the atmosphere itself (see {muD:n:2} (def'n 2)).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for weather, meaning the state of the atmosphere, is the same word as for the atmosphere itself (see {muD:n:1} (def'n 1)). When inquiring about weather conditions at a specific time and/or place, the expression {muD Dotlh:n} is used.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon word for "weather" in the sense of the state of the atmosphere is just {muD:n:2} (def'n 2), the same word as for the atmosphere itself ({muD:n:1} (def'n 1)). The expression {muD Dotlh:n:nolink} is used when inquiring about weather conditions at a specific time and/or place.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is plural. Its singular form is unknown.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is similar to {magh:v}, and as the proverb goes, "a translator is a traitor".

table.name: mem
table.column: If this refers to a person, its plural takes the {-pu':n:suff} suffix. If it refers to a device, its plural takes the {-mey:n:suff} suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column: {vImuHlu' net wuqHa'!:sen:nolink} "My death sentence was commuted!"[2]

table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Do not confuse this with {waH:v:2}, which means "taste" in the sense of trying out food to see if it's been properly prepared or to determine if one likes it.[2]

mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {HoSghaj; mupwI' rur}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
A {mutlhwI':n:nolink} is a person who puts things together.
A person who repairs things is a {tI'wI':n}. Most {mutlhwI'pu':n:nolink} are also {tI'wI'pu':n:nolink}.
When applied to {tlhIm:n}, {mutlh:v:nolink} means to assemble the carpet. The verb for laying a carpet is {vel:v}.
▶ {ngogh mutlhwI':n} "bricklayer" ▶ {majyang mutlhwI':n} "tiler" ▶ {beb mutlhwI':n} "roofer" ▶ {'och mutlhwI':n} "plumber" ▶ {'ul pat mutlhwI':n} "electrician"

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject does the uniting, while the objects are united.
▶ {Qo'noS tuqmey muvchuqmoH qeylIS:sen:nolink} "Kahless united the tribes of Kronos"[1, p.179]

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is how vocabulary used by older Klingons in everyday speech is referred to by younger Klingons.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the vocabulary used by younger Klingons.

table.name: mem
table.column: curse warfare, a kind of sport

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for the planning of an event, a battle strategy, etc., but not for the designing of a physical object (the word for that is {ren:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the planning of an event, and not to the plan of a physical object (i.e., a blueprint, which would be a {pu'jIn:n}).

table.column: stone panel (artwork, similar to a painting)
See {mIllogh:n} for a more general word for "picture".

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear if this is considered a body part (i.e., takes {-Du':n:suff}), but it probably works the same way as for {DIr:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Known types of gemstones include {DIlyum:n}, {qevaS:n}, and {Separ:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: By itself, {naH:n} usually refers to {Du' naH:n} rather than {naH tlhab:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiom refers to one's youthful days (a time before reaching an age considered appropriate for marriage).
{naH jajmeywIj betleH vIyanbe'.:sen:nolink} "In my vegetable days, I did not wield a bat'leth."

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {jejHa'; naH taj rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to fruits or vegetables not grown on a farm, as opposed to {Du' naH:n}.[1, p.89]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is also spelled {neHjej:n:nolink}.
Do not confuse this word with {naQjej:n}.

In the body text of {KGT:src}, this word is spelled {naHjej:n:nolink}, with a note that it literally means "sharp fruit".[1, p.88] However, it is spelled {neHjej:n:nolink} in both the E-K and K-E word lists.

table.name: mem
table.column: One typically {choptaH:v} on the nut, then {tlhIS:v} the pieces of shell.[1, p.87]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a hypothetical component that is found in {loDnal:n}, {be'nal:n}, {nalqaD:n}, as well as {'e'nal:n}. According to {KCD:src}, {nal:n:hyp,nolink} is not used as a word on its own.

table.name: mem
table.column: It seems that this word is composed of {nal:n:hyp}, a component found also in {loDnal:n} and {be'nal:n}, and {qaD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: the familiar beginning of a song
After hearing just this short portion of the beginning of the song, a listener will recognize the tune.

table.name: mem
table.column: {HQ 10.2:src} says that this refers to "a particularly effective martial arts kick".
It's not entirely clear whether this is a verb or a noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: This may have originated with the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect's pronunciation of {DaQ:n}.[1, p.154]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Parts of a spear are its shaft {tIH:n:2} and its spearhead {QIn:n:2}. Types of spears include {ghIntaq:n} and {chonnaQ:n}.
Do not confuse this word with {naHjej:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used idiomatically with {'eb:n} to describe missed or lost opportunities.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: If the warrior's spirit has not escaped, the battle is still going on.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {naS; norgh rur}.[1, p.132]

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear if {tlhuch:v} "exhaust" means "to use something up completely".

table.name: mem
table.column: be reprehensible, be disgusting, be contemptible
In its slang meaning, this verb does not take an object.[1, p.155]

table.name: mem
table.column: A {nawlogh:n:nolink} may or may not belong to a {yo':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TKD:src}, this word is listed as a noun in the E-K side, and as a verb in the K-E side.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TKD:src}, this word is listed as a noun in the E-K side, and as a verb in the K-E side.

table.name: mem
table.column: be sure, be definite, be positive, be certain

table.name: mem
table.column: This fruit is sweet. {na'ran rur} describes something sweet in taste.
The Sanskrit word for orange is "naarang".

table.name: mem
table.column: The meaning of this word is similar to that of {QaS:n:1}, but it includes officers ({yaS:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear why Federation Standard corrupted the spelling of this word by adding an extraneous {qaghwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This follows the verb it modifies, and has the effect of trivializing the action.
This adverbial can also follow a noun, in which case it means "only" or "alone".

table.name: mem
table.column: When this is the verb in the sentence sentence of a sentence-as-object construction, neither {'e':n:pro} nor {net:n:pro} are used.[1]
{qatlh tuneH?:sen:nolink} "What do you want with me?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: See the example for an illustration of the difference between this word and {Sam:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be mature, be grown-up, be adult

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qaSDI' nenghep, qa' patlh chu' chav tlhIngan SuvwI'. poSDaq nIHDaq je QamtaHvIS SuvwI'pu'. chaH jojDaq yItnIS lopwI'. luchovmeH 'oy'naQmey lo'.:sen:nolink} "The Age of Ascension marks a new level of spiritual attainment by a Klingon warrior. The initiate must pass through a gauntlet of warriors who test him with painsticks."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This pronoun is used in a sentence-as-object construction when the second sentence has an indefinite third-person subject (i.e., "one" or "someone").
Sometimes, {'e':n:pro} with {-lu':v} is used instead of {net:n:pro,nolink}. It is not clear why at the moment.

(using {X net Y:sen:nolink}) ▶ {qama'pu' DIHoH net Sov:sen:nolink} "One knows we kill prisoners." ({TKD p.66:src}) ▶ {Qu'vaD lI' net tu'bej:sen:nolink} "One certains finds it useful for the mission." ({TKD p.66:src}) ▶ {Duj ghajchugh pagh, beylI'vo' 'oH Daje' net chaw'.:sen:nolink} "If (the ship is) unowned, you may buy it from the Bank." ({Klingon Monopoly:src})
(using {X 'e' Y-lu':sen:nolink}) ▶ {yInlu'taH 'e' bajnISlu'.:sen} "Survival must be earned." ({TKW p.125:src}) ▶ {yay chavlu' 'e' bajnISlu'.:sen} "Victory must be earned." ({TKW p.125:src}) ▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue." ({Klingon Monopoly:src}) ▶ {Qang QanmeH yan 'ISletlh Damuv 'e' wIvlu'.:sen:nolink} "You are chosen to serve on the Yan-Isleth and protect the Chancellor." ({Klingon Monopoly:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the Klingon word for "ten thousand" is independent of the words for "ten" ({maH:n:1,num}) and "thousand" ({SaD:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: myriad (a period of ten thousand years)
To indicate "tens of thousands of years ago" or "tens of thousands of years from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: type of pot with handles (used for food preparation)

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject of {nIb:v:nolink} are the things which are identical.[2]
The use of this verb does not suggest in what way the things are identical, except when it is used in the following construction.
This verb is used to express the concept that two things have the same amount of some quality, in a similar manner to {rap:v}, but with the connotation of preciseness. If the quality is a measurable one, the connotation is that the two things have exactly the same amount of that quality. See the example below.[3]
▶ {'ugh ro'qegh'Iwchab, nIb raHta'.:sen:nolink} "The racht is as heavy as the rokeg blood pie." (i.e., they are exactly the same weight)

table.name: mem
table.column: In slang, to "nick" something is to steal it.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is how Klingons might refer to a lump or block ({ngogh:n:nolink}) of Terran cheese.

table.name: mem
table.column: How much fuel do we have?
In {TKD p.170:src} and {CK:src}, this is given as "How much fuel do we have left?"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined in {TKD:src} as "hinder, interfere" and in {TKDA:src} as "disrupt, interfere (with)".

▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used only for the Klingon weapon. The more general term for a weapon of this type is {pu':n:1} (def'n 1).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is erroneously given as {nISwI' bej:n:nolink} in {KGT p.56,80:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: These are powerful disruptors mounted on a ship.

table.name: mem
table.column: be plain, be pure, be uncorrupted, be unsullied
Purists are always picking "nit"s. Also, a "neat" alcoholic drink is one served without ice or mixer.

table.name: mem
table.column: nIteb Qob qaD jup 'e' chaw'be' SuvwI'.
A warrior does not let a friend face danger alone.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {nISwI' - cha' chang'engmey (telDaq lujomlu', nItebHa' lubaHlu'):sen:nolink} "Disruptor - 2 pairs (Wing Mounted, Fire Linked)[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word refers to any digit on the hand, including the thumb.
Klingon has five verbs corresponding to each of the {nItlh:n:nolink}: {Sen:v}, {SIq:v}, {qay:v}, {qew:v}, and {qan:v:2}. In addition, when referring to a child's thumb, {rIl:v:1} is used instead of {Sen:v}.
Correspondingly, the fingers are called {SenwI':n} ({rIlwI':n} if it belongs to a child), {SIqwI':n}, {qaywI':n}, {qewwI':n}, and {qanwI':n}.
See {SIq:v} for an explanation of the usage of these finger verbs.
The verbs for the fingers come from names of the Finger Lakes in New York State.

table.name: mem
table.column: flat end of a pigment stick

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to something that seems to appear, but isn't really there. It does not refer to a ghost or spirit, and is quite different from {qa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Don't trust Yridians who bring gifts.

table.name: mem
table.column: Contrast this with {veS:n}, which refers to the concept of warfare.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the dialect of this region, toasts do not use special grammar, and the subject follows the verb in toasts just as they do in regular sentences (see {-jaj:v}).

This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.26 and not in the glossary. It appears as {noHva'Dut:n:nolink} and not as {noHva'Dut Sep:n:nolink}, but it is implied that this is the name of a region (see {Sep:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.
Destroying an empire to win a war is no victory, and ending a battle to save an empire is no defeat.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a Klingon idiom, {nong; vulqangan rur}, which is meant ironically.

table.name: mem
table.column: "NOP" is a no-op, a computer command to do nothing.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of animal, norg (shark-like sea creature)
There is an idiom, {naS; norgh rur}.[1, p.132]

table.name: mem
table.column: The use of this verb is derogatory (except for children and pets).
This is the Yiddish word for nibble, "nosh". It's also similar to the German verb "naschen".

table.name: mem
table.column: {not jegh tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon warrior never surrenders."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: No Klingon ever breaks his word.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is nowhere near as large as a {qa'rol:n}, which is really big.
This is a reference to "The Raven" by Poe.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {notlh veS.:sen:nolink} "War is obsolete."[2] ▶ {notlh tonSaw'lIj.:sen} "Your fighting technique is obsolete."

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "Your fighting technique is obsolete."

table.name: mem
table.column: The joke is that this word is before {nung:n} in {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: society; group of people with shared culture
Do not confuse this with a society in the scholarly sense, which is called a {yej'an:n}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was used in the title of a thesis in sociology, "Klingon as Linguistic Capital: A Sociologic Study of Nineteen Advanced Klingonists" {Hol Sup 'oH tlhIngan Hol'e'; wa'maH Hut tlhIngan Hol po'wI' nughQeD:sen:nolink}, by Yens Wahlgren. This usage was approved by MO.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is influenced by the {Qotmagh Sep:n} pronunciation of {DuH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A {nuH bey':n:nolink} has one {betleH:n}, one {naQjej:n}, and one {ghob'etlh:n:hyp}.[1]
There is also a picture of one on {TKW p.124:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: You have chosen your weapon, so fight!

table.name: mem
table.column: Based on its use in the "Friend of Maltz" {matlh jupna':n:nolink} certificates, this means "promote" in the sense of promoting an activity or advocating for a cause. However, the certificates are considered by some to be non-canon.
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Danummo' pIquvmoH.} "Because you promote the Klingon language, we honor you."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: MO confirmed at {Saarbrucken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that {nup:v:nolink} is intransitive.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word fits into a sentence in the place which would be occupied by the answer.[1] It works like a pronoun in questions with "to be" in the English translations.[2]
Questions in English often map more naturally to imperatives in Klingon. If you want to ask a "what" question, consider using a command with a verb such as {ngu':v} instead.[2] For example, consider {per:v}, {ja':v}, {Del:v}, etc.
Also, note that "What are your orders?" is expressed in Klingon as {chay' jura'?:sen:nolink} See {chay':ques}.
▶ {yIH nuq?:sen:nolink} "What is a tribble?"[2] ▶ {nuq mI'lIj?:sen}[3] ▶ {Dochvam nuq?:sen:nolink} "What is this?"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Where do I put this? What do I do with this?

table.name: mem
table.column: To ask where a person is, {ghaH:n} should be used instead of {'oH:n}. {nuqDaq ghaH ...'e'?:sen:nolink} "Where is ...?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Where do you keep the chocolate?

table.name: mem
table.column: what did you say? huh? what?
This is in clipped Klingon. The grammatical way to ask "What did you say?" would be {nuq Dajatlh?:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column:
This exclamation is not the equivalent of "hello". The greeted party is expected to simply begin speaking speaking rather than return the greeting.[2; 3]
Note that this exclamation is in clipped Klingon. The grammatical way to ask "What do you want?" would be {nuq DaneH?:sen:nolink}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {CK:src}, the Klingon hotel clerk asks the Terran visitor, {nuq mI'lIj, tera'ngan?:sen:nolink} But this question works as well for telephone numbers as it does for hotel guest numbers.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a Class M planet which is home to the mugato.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This refers to physical stability. To refer to an unstable person, use {ngIj:v}.[1, p.150]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Cantonese word for "bite" or "chew".

table.name: mem
table.column: be locked, be sealed, be secured, be fastened
There is an idiomatic expression, {ngaQ lojmIt:sen}, which means that an outcome is unavoidable or a course of action irrevocable.

table.name: mem
table.column: For something like a keycard, some Klingon speakers unofficially use {lojmIt chaw':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression means that a situation has an unavoidable outcome, or a plan or commitment is firm and cannot be changed.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being contained. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is mixed with {tIr:n} and used to {pID:v} food.[1, p.89]

table.name: mem
table.column: mixing stick with flattened, paddlelike end
This is a {DuDwI':n} with a paddlelike end.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is known only from {wo' ngay' bochoqmeH bowIvlu'pu'!:sen:nolink} "You have been chosen to preserve the glory of the Empire!" from {Klingon Monopoly:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject of this verb is all the involved parties.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {tlhab; ngem Ha'DIbaH rur}.[1, p.132]

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression means that something is complex. It is often used in the form {ngem Sarghmey tlha'laH:sen:nolink} to describe someone who is capable of a difficult feat.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The shore of a lake is its {HeH:n}.
The lava-filled area of a volcano is called its {qul ngeng:n:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In some {meqro'vaq Sep:n} dialects, this refers to any stairway but a {choghvat:n}, which is called a {letlh:n:2} there.

table.name: mem
table.column: bump into, run into, collide with
This describes the collision of something moving with something stationary.[1] Unlike {paw':v:1}, {ngeQ:v:nolink} has an innocent party.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a person, although it can be used to translate the word "store" or "shop". In {TNK:src}, "Where is the shop?" is translated as {nuqDaq ghaH ngevwI''e'?:sen:nolink} Note that {ghaH:n} is used rather than {'oH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ankle (also a slang term of deprecation)

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink} "Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used in {TNK:src} in the sentence {nuqDaq puH Duj vIngIp?:sen:nolink} to mean "Where can I hire (rent) a car?" However, it's not clear that the Klingon sentence expresses the idea that the car is to be borrowed for money.

table.name: mem
table.column: This noun indicates that a single thing is being considered apart from others, or that a sequence of identical things is considered one after another. Like {Hoch:n} and {'op:n}, it precedes what it modifies.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {Honor Bound:src}, this is a type of lubricant used on disruptor cannons.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tlhIlHal yIngIv!} "Patrol the mine!"[2, p.191] ▶ {jogh veH lungIv.} "They patrol the quadrant border."[2, p.194]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'.:sen:nolink} "There, the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Trekbits" was translated as {Hov leng ngoDHommey:n:nolink} in {STC 104:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who assembles bricks into something, such as a wall or a building.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons don't have pillows, but Maltz said this is what he would call one if he had to call it something.

table.name: mem
table.column: move bat'leth from horizontal to vertical orientation

table.name: mem
table.column: {vangDI' tlhIngan SuvwI' ngoy' qorDu'Daj; vangDI' qorDu'Daj ngoy' tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that in Klingon, there is a different word for "be old (not new)" ({ngo':v:nolink}) than for "be old (not young)" ({qan:v:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
This adverbial is used mainly to emphasize that one event occurred at the same time as another. It does not mean "at some (vague) time in the past" or "at some (unknown) time in the future".[1]
For a verb with a similar meaning, see {quq:v}. For an idiom meaning "by that time", see {pumDI':sen}.
Note that "then" in the sense of "subsequently" is {ghIq:adv}.[1]
▶ {DungluQ tIHIv. ngugh Qongbe' chaH.:sen:nolink} "Attack them at noon! They won't be sleeping then."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: If a bird lands on land, the verb {Saq:v} is used, and if on water, then {tlhot:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: authority, power, one in authority or in charge

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the faction that controls most of the Gamma Quadrant.

table.name: mem
table.column: be dyed, be stained, be tinted

This word is seldom used except in the question {chay' nguv?:sen:nolink} or when suffixed with {-moH:v} to form {nguvmoH:v}.[1, p.82]
Besides {chIS:v} and {qIj:v}, there are only two known color words in Klingon, {Doq:v} and {SuD:v:1}. The latter two words are suffixed with {-qu':v}, and/or combined with {wov:v} and {Hurgh:v}, to refer to more specific colors. To be even more specific, comparisons are used, such as {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "what" question in English is often best translated into Klingon using the imperative form of this or a similar verb.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Some possible objects of this verb are {pab:n}, {chut:n}, {nab:n}, {'Ip:n}, and {lurDech:n}.
In the context of a vow or promise which has been made (see {'Ip:v} and {lay':v}), {pab:v:nolink} means "to keep" or "to fulfill".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a canonical word, but it is commonly known among speakers of Klingon as it is used on the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n} mailing list.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {jej:v} and {jejHa':v} for two idiomatic expressions involving {pach:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to describe something that was expected to occur, or could conceivably occur, but has not.
▶ {pawpu' 'avwI' paghDIch:sen:nolink} "the zeroth guard has arrived" (no guard has arrived even though one or more are expected)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an emphatic alternative for {not:adv}.
{paghlogh jegh tlhIngan SuvwI':sen:nolink} "A Klingon warrior never surrenders", literally, "A Klingon warrior surrenders zero times".

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, the conjunction {pagh:conj} cannot be used to present two options to someone, such as "surrender or die". {bIjegh pagh bIHegh:sen:nolink} means "you're surrendering or you're dying" (as if the speaker is not sure which is happening). Instead, the sentence must be recast as "If you don't surrender, you will die". See {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen} for further information.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined in {TKD:src} as "gown". In {TNK:src}, it is used for "dress", while {paH bID:n} is used for "skirt".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {pan qeylIS betleH 'ej jach molor 'etlh HoS:sen:nolink} "Kahless's bat'leth sparks, And Molor's mighty sword roars."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon Dictionary was published by Pocket Books. See also {buq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The son of Torghn ({torghen:n:name}), and the main character of the holodeck simulation in {KCD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the name of a book recounting the legendary life and deeds of {qeylIS:n}. Note that the name of the book is in {no' Hol:n}, and that in modern standard Klingon "Book of Honor" would be {batlh paq:n:nolink}; the apostrophe represents what may be a missing grammatical element that would explain the transposition.[1]
The {paq'batlh:n:nolink} is divided into three major parts, titled respectively {paq'yav:n:nolink} "Ground Book", {paq'raD:n:nolink} "Force Book", and {paq'QIH:n:nolink} "Impact Book".
See also {tIq'ghob:n:hyp} for a hypothetical similar grammatical construction.

table.name: mem
table.column: a mid-sized bird with particularly garish coloring (at least from a Klingon point of view)
a mid-sized bird with particularly garish colouring

table.name: mem
table.column: Love, Klingon style -- with much more intense connotations than the English word.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom} for an idiomatic expression related to lateness, and {'eb:n} for some examples of how to express the concept of "too late".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is plural. It is unknown if a singular form exists.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Hung buv rav; patlh Hut:sen:nolink} "Classified Level 9 and Above"[3] ▶ {qaSDI' nenghep, qa' patlh chu' chav tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen:nolink} "The Age of Ascension marks a new level of spiritual attainment by a Klingon warrior."[4] ▶ {SIQwI' lu'oy'moHmeH juppu'Daj 'oy'naQmey lo' chaH. SuvwI' qa' patlh veb chavlaHmeH tlhIngan lo'chu' chaH. toDujDaj toblu'.:sen:nolink} "The Painstik is employed by friends of the recipent who use the devices to inflict pain in a manner which will allow the Klingon to attain a higher state of spirituality as a warrior, proving his mettle."[5]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Qugh la'vaD QIn pav.:sen:nolink} "Urgent message for Commander Kruge."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
{paw:v:nolink} works in a similar way to {jaH:v}.[2]
Do not confuse this with {paw':v:1}.
▶ {Duj vIpaw.:sen:nolink} or {DujDaq vIpaw.:sen:nolink} (the {-Daq:n} is optional) "I arrive at the ship." ▶ {DujDaq jIpaw.:sen:nolink} "I arrive on the ship." That is, "I arrive via the ship."

table.name: mem
table.column:
The verb {paw':v:nolink} always takes a plural subject, namely, the things in motion which collide. When the subject is people, the verb is usually interpreted with the slang meaning of "butting heads" (see {paw':v:2,slang} (def'n 2)). To describe the collision of something moving with something stationary, use {ngeQ:v} instead.[2; 3]
Do not confuse this with {paw:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: As with the literal usage of this verb (see {paw':v:1} (def'n 1)), when used in its slang meaning, it also takes a plural subject, in this case the people who butt heads. To say that two people collide without implying that they are butting heads, {ngeQ:v} might be used with {-chuq:v:suff}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Another way of saying "You'll regret this!" is "You'll pay for this!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is homophonous with {pa':n:2}. However, {pa'Daq:n:nolink} unambiguously means "in the room".
The {bIS'ub:n} of a {pa':n:1} is its {rav:n:1}, and its {'aqroS:n:1} is its {rav'eq:n}. If the {pa':n:1} is in the top story of a {qach:n}, then its {rav'eq:n} is called its {pa' beb:n}. The walls of a {pa':n:1} are {tlhoy':n}; if the other side of a wall is {Hur:n}, then the wall is also called a {pa' reD:n}. The word {tlhoy':n} can refer to any side of a room; a ceiling/floor between stories is called a {tlhoy' SaS:n}.

This word is defined as "room" in {TKD:src}, as "enclosed area" in {KGT:src}, and as "chamber" in {BoP:src} (see {cha'puj pa':n}). Furthermore, the "enclosed area" definition is marked as slang in the K-E word list in {KGT:src}, but not in the E-K word list.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is homophonous with {pa':n:1}. As a locative, {pa':n:2} never takes the suffix {-Daq:n:suff}, and can only mean "there" ({TKD 3.3.5:src}). In contrast, {pa'Daq:n:nolink} can only mean "in the room".

table.name: mem
table.column: Kinds of {pa'mey:n:nolink} include {yaS pa'mey:n}, {beq pa'mey:n}, and {mebpa'mey:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the ceiling of a room which is on the top (or only) story of a structure. If there are rooms above it, then it is a {rav'eq:n}.[1]
ceiling of a top storey room

table.name: mem
table.column: This is soaked in {chanDoq:n} and eaten.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can also be used without an object. See {pegh:v:2} (def'n 2).

table.name: mem
table.column:
See {rav:n:2} for an example of how to talk about classified information.
This verb can also be used with an object. See {pegh:v:1} (def'n 1).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also infrequently shortened to {pegh vIttlhegh:n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiomatic expression {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom} "before it breaks its shell", meaning "before it's too late" or "while there's still time".

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "before it breaks its shell", and as an idiomatic expression it has the meaning of "before it's too late" or "while there's still time".
{pel'aQDaj ghorpa' qama' yIHoH.:sen:nolink} "Kill the prisoner now, while you've got a chance."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the part of the day when it is light out (as opposed to {ram:n}).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Cardassian Union.

table.name: mem
table.column: {bISuvtaHvIS qarDaS bIghHa' peQ botjan Daveghchu'.:sen:nolink} "Fight your way beyond magnetic shield of Cardassian prison."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is written as {peQ chem:n:nolink} (with a space) in {TKDA:src}. The space has been removed for consistency with the other terms ending in {chem:n:hyp}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {per:v:nolink} usually means "to assign or attach a name to", but it can also be used for such notions as "ascertain, specify, pin down". One way to ask for the time is {rep yIper!:sen}, literally, "Label the hour!"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: A code name usually ends in {Qu':n}, e.g., {targh Qu':n:nolink} "Operation Targ".[1, p.48]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is one of the most common Klingon epithets.
There's an explanation of the origin of this word on {paq'batlh p.70:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Triticale is a hybridization of wheat (genus Triticum) and rye (genus Secale). {pev:n:hyp,nolink} is not a known word, it is known only as an element in the word {loSpev:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is almost how "pH" is pronounced in French.

table.name: mem
table.column: to do something at once, as a single event
This idiomatic expression literally means "to forcefully sweep away".
{romuluSnganpu' Dujmey DIQaw'pu'; pe'vIl DIbI'chu'pu'.} "We destroyed the Romulans' ships all at once."

table.name: mem
table.column:
This idiomatic expression conveys the idea that someone is particularly agile or nimble or spry.
The verb {roS:v:2} means "to use the third toe". It is also homophonous with a verb {roS:v:1} meaning "to lick". However, it's possible that this verb is actually an otherwise unknown or archaic verb {roS:v:3,hyp} meaning "to be agile".

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {ghaj:v} is used with this noun to indicate fault or blame.

table.name: mem
table.column: Don't trust those who frequently smile.

table.name: mem
table.column: be stimulated, be inspired, be motivated

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to music.[1, p.71]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: In this slang sense, {pIn:n:nolink} is never used alone, but is always the second noun in a noun-noun construction. The non-slang term for "expert" is {po'wI':n}.[1, p.158]

table.name: mem
table.column: Its claws are used as food and require breaking.

table.name: mem
table.column: pIpyuS pach DaSop DaneHchugh pIpyuS puS DaghornIS.
If you want to eat pipius claw, you'll have to break a few pipiuses.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an expression telling someone (often a child) to get started on something or to devote more effort to a project.

table.name: mem
table.column:
A specialised word is used to indicate a time in the future for the following units: ▶ {jaj:n} "day" - {leS:n} "days from now" ▶ {jar:n} "month" - {waQ:n} "months from now" ▶ {DIS:n:2} "year" - {nem:n} "years from now"
For other units of time, {pIq:n:nolink} is used.

table.name: mem
table.column: Little is know about how {pIqaD:n:nolink} works, except that it is not an alphabet.[2]
If interpreted as a sentence, {pIqaD} literally means "we challenge you".

table.name: mem
table.column: be indirect, be roundabout, be devious

table.name: mem
table.column: The moon of the Klingon Homeworld ({Qo'noS:n}), and the site of a major energy facility ({HoS waw':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the underside of an object, and not to its interior bottom (which is its {bIS'ub:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran food. To Klingons, pizzas are apparently a kind of {chab:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: done (uttered at the completion of a task)

table.name: mem
table.column: This actually appears in the plural on the {BoP:src} poster: {pIvchem lIngwI' DaHmey:n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: animal that makes noise at dawn
This is the literary name for a {'uSgheb:n} or a {jajlo' Qa':n}. It is commonly used in operas and plays, but rarely in everyday speech.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the K-E side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {mIvDaq pogh cha':sen} for an idiom involving {pogh:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: To indicate "period of time ago" or "period of time from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: the matter is unimportant, it does not make a difference
This idiomatic expression literally means someone "can either keep it or discard it".

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This sentence does not appear explicitly in {TKD:src}, but can be constructed using nothing but the vocabulary and grammar presented in it.[1] The sentence in {paq'batlh:src} has a typo: it says {pongwI''e':sen:nolink} rather than {pongwIj'e':sen:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: {roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH.:sen:nolink} "[Qo'noS] is usually referred to as simply 'The Homeworld'."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Any formal recognition of an accomplishment or accomplishments.

table.name: mem
table.column: {loHwI' vISuch 'e' vIpoQ!:sen:nolink} "I demand to see the magistrate!"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the best temperature to serve blood wine.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz had a hard time thinking of an everyday sentence containing this phrase.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons don't talk all that much about bodily functions as a group, but they certainly do talk about specific bodily functions (see {porgh mIw:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {HoD, yo'SeH yaHnIvvo' potlh De' wIHevtaH.:sen:nolink} "Captain, we are receiving a priority message from Operations Command." This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: If winning is not important, then why keep score?

table.name: mem
table.column: This is considered too potent for tourists.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word lists say "washroom". The "bathroom" definition comes from the example sentence on p.170.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a known word, and exists as an element in the word {cha'puj:n} and possibly also in the word {beqpuj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no honor in attacking the weak.
There is no honour in attacking the weak.

table.name: mem
table.column: by that time, by the time that (something) occurred

This idiomatic expression literally means "when it falls". It is most frequently heard without a subject, but when a subject is specified, the most common is {'etlh:n}. Another word may be chosen as the subject as a form of word play, as long as it is something that can fall (e.g., {DaS:n}, {'obmaQ:n}, {nagh:n}, {rutlh:n}). When used idiomatically, {pumDI':sen:nolink} always precedes the main clause.[1]
▶ {tagha' pawpu' meb 'ach pumDI' Heghpu' qagh.:sen:nolink} "The guest finally arrived, but by then the gagh had died."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the conjunction {ghap:conj} normally follows the nouns it's joining.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used only when speaking to young children or pets.

table.name: mem
table.column: This phrase does not appear in canon, but it is an obvious derivation from canonical terms.

table.name: mem
table.column: To say "to smoke" (as in inhale nicotine), use {tlhIch pur:sen:nolink}.
The words for inhale and exhale together sound like "poor wretch" ({pur rech:sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: be few, be several, be a handful
The word {puS:v:nolink} is used in comparative constructions. See {... X law' ... X puS:sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is descended from the archaic word for "spike" ({pu':n:2,archaic} (def'n 2)).
The Klingon equivalent to a phaser is a {nISwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the archaic word for what is now called {DaSpu':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is misspelled {pu'bej:n:nolink} on {KGT p.56:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: map, plan (as in a building plan), blueprint
This word refers to the plan of a physical object, and not to a procedure or the plan for an event (which would be {nab:n}).
Augustus W. N. Pugin was an English architect who assisted in the design of the Palace of Westminster.

table.name: mem
table.column: On {TKW p.59:src}, it is explained one's face is shown as a symbol of identity or honor. See also {cha' qabDu':n} and {qabDu' law':n} for idiomatic uses of this word.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression refers to a group participating in a single activity. For example, a brawl may be described by saying {Suv qabDu' law':sen:nolink} "Many faces are fighting".
many people, a lot of people, lots of people, multitude, crowd

table.name: mem
table.column:
The {yor:n} of a {qach:n} is its {beb:n}, and its {Hur:n}-facing walls are called {reD:n}. The other side of the {beb:n} (that is, the {'aqroS:n:1} of a {qach:n}) is called the {pa' beb:n}; the {qoD:n} face of a {reD:n} is referred to as {pa' reD:n}.
For the {qoD:n} parts of a {qach:n}, see {pa':n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {ngup qaD:sen:nolink}, literally "challenge the cape", which describes someone who is unsatisfied with the status quo and wants to challenge those in charge. See {ngup:n}.[2, p.157]

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {A Burning House:src}, this is a raised, fenced platform in the plaza outside the headquarters of the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The names of the consonants consist of the sound followed by {ay:sen:nolink}, and the vowels' names consist of the sound preceded by {':sen:nolink} and followed by {t:sen:nolink}. The glottal stop is an exception.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is often written in English as "gagh".
There is an idiom, {ghung; qagh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "to kill gagh (serpent worms)", which should be eaten live. This idiomatic expression is applied to someone who is doing something counterproductive.
{SuyDuj DaQaw'chugh qagh DaHoH.:sen:nolink} This indicates that destroying the merchant ship would be contrary to the best interests of the current mission.

table.name: mem
table.column: gagh stew, gagh served as leftovers

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is never heard except in direct address.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word literally means "fiery lava" on Krios. It implies courage of a surprising or unexpected kind, perhaps even recklessness (unlike {toDuj:n} which is more neutral).[1, p.10]

table.name: mem
table.column: The parts of a foot include its {bem:n} "sole", {mov:n} "top (of foot)", and {yaD:n:1} "toe(s)". The foot is attached to the {'uS:n} "leg" through the {ngIb:n} "ankle".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call a Terran bicycle.

table.name: mem
table.column: MO accomodated by changing {qama'} to mean prisoner while {Star Trek III:src} was being filmed.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to legend, this is the name of an ancient village on {Qo'noS:n} where Kahless and Lukara fought a great battle against hundreds of enemies, a major component of their courtship.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that in Klingon, there is a different word for "be old (not new)" ({ngo':v}) than for "be old (not young)" ({qan:v:1,nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: An idiomatic gesture (due to homophony with {qan:v:1} (def'n 1)): to point your pinkie at someone is to comment that you believe they are old.
{qI'empeqDaq jIqan.} "I think that K'mpec is old."

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird known for its song

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {qanwI':n:nolink} can also mean "old person". An idiomatic gesture: to point your pinkie at someone is to comment that you believe they are old.

table.name: mem
table.column: always agree with, always cooperate with

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used in forming tag questions with the suffix {-'a':v:suff}. In such a question, {qar'a':sen:nolink} either follows the verb, or comes at the end of the sentence. ({TKDA 6.4:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: Fire the torpedoes at my command!

table.name: mem
table.column: The Cardassian Homeworld, the main planet of the Cardassian Union. Also called {qarDaSya':n:nolink}[1, p.141-142] and {qarDaS wa':n:nolink} (Cardassia Prime)[2].

table.name: mem
table.column: {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: bird capable of mimicking speech, larger than {qaryoq:n}
Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This sentence doesn't appear exactly in canon, but {qaStaH nuq jay'?:sen:nolink} "What the #$*@ is happening?" appears on {TKD p.177:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.
Four thousand throats may be cut in one night by a running man.

table.name: mem
table.column: qaStaHvIS wej puq poHmey vav puqloDpu' puloDpu'chaj je quvHa'moH vav quvHa'ghach.
The dishonor of the father dishonors his sons and their sons for three generations.
The dishonour of the father dishonours his sons and their sons for three generations.

table.name: mem
table.column: {qaSuj'a'?:sen:nolink} is how you would ask the question if you're speaking to only one person. To ask a group of people if you're disturbing them, say {SaSuj'a'?:sen:nolink} "Am I disturbing you (plural)?"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to the "Why a Duck?" routine from the Marx Brothers movie "The Cocoanuts".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote how many {QaS:n:1} a player has to pay when landing on a planet owned by another player.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bomDI' 'IwwIj qaqaw.:sen} ▶ {batlh Daqawlu'taH.:sen} "You will be remembered with honor."

table.name: mem
table.column:
Based on the example, the subject does the reminding, the object is the thing remembered, and the person who is reminded is marked with {-vaD:n}.
More generally, it seems that when {-moH:v} is added to a verb {X:sen:nolink} which takes an object, the resulting bivalent verb {XmoH:sen:nolink} takes the same object, while the original subject of {X:sen:nolink} becomes the beneficiary of {XmoH:sen:nolink} and is marked with {-vaD:n}.

▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be a problem, be a hassle

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject does the replacing, and the object is replaced.
{Quj wa'DIch MONOPOLY Huch nav qa' tlhIngan QaS:sen:nolink} "Klingon forces replace original MONOPOLY bills"

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a sort of life force within a person which escapes when that person dies.[2]
This is an acceptable word to use for "ghost", but there may be another (and better) unknown word for that concept.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: We fight to enrich the spirit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was originally a shortened form of {quvqa'meH:sen:nolink} (see {qa'meH vIttlegh:n}), but has since become accepted as a noun in its own right. It refers to something that takes over for or is used instead of something that is gone or which has been lost. To denote a temporary substitute or stand-in, use {lIw:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the past, this used to be {quvqa'meH vIttlhegh:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Its claw is eaten. This word may also be spelled {Qa'raj:n:nolink}.
Do not confuse this with the similarly named {Qaj:n}.
On {KGT p.94:src}, this word is spelled {qa'raj:n:nolink}. However, it is spelled {Qa'raj:n:nolink} in both the E-K and K-E word lists.

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of corridor, tunnel, conduit, Jeffries tube, sewer, road, bridge, long field, etc.)
This is the end of any clearly defined space longer than wide in which people might find themselves.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is much larger than a {notqa':n}.
The character of Big Bird on the children's show Sesame Street is played by Caroll Edwin Spinney.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Klingon code name for the Federation's Genesis weapons research project. Its meaning is otherwise unknown.
▶ {qa'vam De' vIje' rIntaH.:sen:nolink} "I have obtained the Genesis data."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: qa'vak (traditional game), game played with hoop and stick
It may just be a coincidence, but this sounds like {qa' vaQ:n:nolink} "aggressive spirit". See {qa':n} and {vaQ:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the action of squeezing the bag part of the {DIron:n}, usually with the elbow.[1, p.76]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {paq'raD:n:nolink} "Force Book" of the {paq'batlh:n}, the second section is titled {qeHHa' loDnI':sen:nolink}, which is given the somewhat loose English translation "A Brother's Forgiveness". A footnote explains that the concept of forgiveness does not map exactly to Klingon culture, and that the literal meaning of the title is "A Brother Unresents". The title of the corresponding canto in the opera {'u':n:name,nolink} is {loDnI'Daj quvqa'moH:sen:nolink}, literally, "he causes the brother to have honor again".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a unit of measurement roughly akin to two kilometers.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {paq'batlh:src}, the {qempa'QeH:n:nolink} are the enraged (see {QeH:v}) ancestral spirits populating {ghe'tor:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: a while back, a long time ago?
This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: A pregnant woman is said to {qeng:v:nolink} a {puq:n}.[2] See {yatlh:v}.

▶ {yatlh luqara' puqloD wa'DIch qenglI'} "Lukara, pregnant of their first-born son"[2] ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Also related are the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v}.
Do not confuse with {Qeq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is sauce prepared by thickening {chanDoq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In its first appearance as a noun, in {HQ 4.4, Dec. 1995:src}, {qev:n:nolink} was described as "[among] those words already well-known for different types of groups". The noun {tlhach:n} was explicitly introduced as being a new word in the same article. This suggests that the verb {qev:v} was misread as a noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traded commodity which, like {DIlyum:n}, is a type of gemstone.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Kahless is the legendary first Klingon Emperor who united the Klingon people.
He is commonly known as "Kahless the Unforgettable" ({qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':sen:nolink}[2] or {qeylIS lIjlaHbogh pagh:sen:nolink}[3]).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is abbreviated QB in the {paq'batlh:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is abbreviated QBV in the {paq'batlh:src}. (This could be a typo for QBN.)

table.name: mem
table.column: Eyes of Kahless, a game played with dice
This is a guessing game with dice in which the winner receives a punch.

table.name: mem
table.column: All fermented meat is known as {qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n:nolink}, with the word for the specific meat replacing the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.
"Kiviak" is an Inuit food made of auks fermented in the body of a seal.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was apparently intended to be {qIb:n} plus {HeH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In English slang, to "kid" is to joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: joke, make a joke, tell a joke
In English slang, to "kid" is to joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb always takes an object or {-chuq:v} in normal usage.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Kill". The "abort" meaning was given at {Saarbrucken qepHom'a' 2011:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

table.name: mem
table.column: Arrows come from "quiv"ers, and you can take an arrow to the knee.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to a message on the {msn:src} newsgroup, Maltz seemed reluctant to talk about what exactly this is.[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: {qI'empeqDaq jIqan.} "I think that K'mpec is old."

table.name: mem
table.column:
This both holds up one's {yopwaH:n} and is used for hanging weapons.[2]
{qoghmey:n:nolink} generally means "belts", but could also mean "ears scattered all about", due to the homophony with {qogh:n:2} (def'n 2). This homophony is also the basis of a slang expression, {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to the external flap of skin, cartilage, or whatever. The internal organ of hearing is called {teS:n}.
{qoghDu':n:nolink} can only mean "ears", while {qoghmey:n:nolink} is usually the plural of {qogh:n:1} (def'n 1) and means "belts". The homophony between these two words is the basis of a slang expression, {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression literally means "take off one's belt". It derives its slang meaning from the homophony between {qogh:n:1} (def'n 1) and {qogh:n:2} (def'n 2).
It's unclear why the expression is {tuQmoHHa':sen:nolink} and not {tuQHa'moH:v}.
{qogh vItuQmoHHa'pu':sen:nolink} "I've taken off my belt; your secret is safe with me."

table.name: mem
table.column: The wind does not respect a fool.

table.name: mem
table.column: This name is untranslated in {KGT:src}, and is possibly a misspelling for {qo'leq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This name is sometimes written as Kortar ({qortar:n:name,nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: To prepare this, {tap:v} a mixture of {naH:n} and animal matter, and let {rogh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used for the act of composing songs, stories, etc.[2, p.71] Klingons consider songs as things which just exist, and the act of composition is viewed as hunting down, trapping, and logging them.[3]
There is another verb, {gher:v}, which is used for compiling lists and the like, and which, in contrast to {qon:v:nolink}, suggests that information is merely passed along.[4]
This is defined as "record" in {TKD:src}, and as "compose" in {KGT:src}.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {qonwI':n:nolink} can also mean a recording device, as in {mIllogh qonwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In English, "cop" is a slang term for a police officer.

table.name: mem
table.column: A {yoqqoq} would, of course, be a "so-called humanoid".
This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon sentence on {SkyBox 13:src} seems to have dropped some words, since it is ungrammatical.
[1] {TKD:src}, [2] {SkyBox 13:src} (reprinted in {HQ 3.4, p.10-11, Dec. 1994:src}), [3] {SkyBox 20:src} (reprinted in {HQ 5.2, p.14, Jun. 1996:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is a rodent that is considered a destructive pest on Klingon farms, where farmers have to set traps for them.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word occurs in {wab qoSta' 'aplo':n} and {mIllogh qonwI' qoSta':n}, but its exact meaning is not otherwise known.

table.name: mem
table.column: {bIyIntaH 'e' Daqotlhbe'.:sen:nolink} "You do not deserve to live." (untranslated, from opening of {PK:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: From the {BoP:src} poster, {qughDo motlh:n:nolink} is "normal cruising speed".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to pieces of animal skin soaked in liquor and set on fire, which must be eaten quickly.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "Eat the fire skin!"

table.name: mem
table.column: House of Fire, name of an opera

table.name: mem
table.column: History is written by the victors.

table.name: mem
table.column: hole (like a hole in a musical instrument)

Based on the explanation in {HQ 10.2:src}, this seems to refer to a hole used to change pitch in a wind instrument, and apparently not to a soundhole for a stringed instrument. However, this is not explicitly stated.[1]
This word can't be used for a hole in the ground (for which see {QemjIq:n}), but it can be used for a bullet hole or a hole in a shirt (including buttonholes, moth holes, accidental rips, etc.). The difference between a {QemjIq:n} and a {qung:n:nolink} is that the former can be filled ({teb:v}).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The subjects are the events that happen simultaneously.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is allegedly the Morskan term for an architect. The {ta' Hol:n} term is {renwI':n}.
This word was suggested by Quvar to MO as a new word for the {Saarbrucken qepHom'a' 2011:src}. It's based on the name of the Swiss-born French architect Le Corbusier.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "to sit in a chair". It is based on the homophony between {ba':v} and {-ba':v:suff}.
{quSDaq bIba'.:sen:nolink} "What you said is quite obvious."

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extraneous space after {ba':sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This weapon is associated symbolically with assassins.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremony in which a young Klingon draws blood for first time.[1, p.62]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {ghaj:v} and {Hutlh:v} can be used with this noun to indicate that someone possesses or lacks honor, respectively.
This refers to personal honor, which is earned by one's behaviour.

▶ {quv lughaj Archer HoD beqDaj je. lengtaH 'e' yIchaw'.:sen:nolink} "Captain Archer and his crew are honorable people. Let them continue on their way."[3] ▶ {quv Hutlh HoHbogh tlhIngan 'ach qabDaj 'angbe'bogh.:sen}[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: A {quv bey':n:nolink} has two {betleH:n} and two {Daqtagh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon who kills without showing his face has no honor.
The Klingon who kills without showing his face has no honour.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingon has more specific words to describe dishonor, which depend on the circumstances of the dishonor. If the honor paid to someone is unearned or undeserved, consider {HoQ:v}. If the dishonor involves deception about one's social status, consider {Qaq:v}. If it involves a fall from grace, consider {mIl:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is simply {quv:v} plus the suffix {-moH:v}, so verb suffixes of types 1 to 3 need to go before {-moH:v}, which is type 4. However, this rule is sometimes broken for rhetorical effect.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the Ferengi bartender on the Federation space station Deep Space Nine.
{quwargh tach Qe' je qoDDaq Hov leng Soj DatIv.} "Enjoy Star Trek themed food and drink at Quark's Bar and Restaurant."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the reverse, {pI'yuq:sen:nolink}, is phonetically "puke".

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is typically applied only to people or animals. When applied to something other than a person or an animal, it is likely that its slang meaning (see {qu':v:2} (def'n 2)) is intended.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be great, be wonderful, be excellent, be splendid

When this verb is applied to a person or an animal, it is not always clear whether the slang or literal meaning (see {qu':v:1} (def'n 1)) is intended. However, when applied to something other than a person or an animal, the slang meaning is more likely.[1, p.159]
Two out-of-fashion slang words with the same meaning are {Huv:v:2,slang} and {nong:v:2,slang}, the latter of which may be making a comeback.[1, p.161]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Gamma Quadrant.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used for wielding or swinging an ax, a club, or the like.[1, p.64]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "be dry" in {TKD:src}, while {KGT:src} extends this with "be dried out".

table.name: mem
table.column: This sense of {QaD:v:2,nolink} comes from its similarity to {Qan:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: err, be mistaken, make a mistake

table.name: mem
table.column: due to your apparent minor errors
This is used in {TKD:src} as an example of a noun with all five suffix types.

table.name: mem
table.column: Have the courage to admit your mistakes.

table.name: mem
table.column: For help on using this program, see under {boQwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: For help on using this program, see under {boQwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
A kradge has brown lips. The expression {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).[2]
Do not confuse this with the similarly named {qa'raj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: QamvIS Hegh qaq law' torvIS yIn qaq puS.
Better to die on our feet than live on our knees.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the title of the leader of the Klingon Empire, when it is not ruled by an Emperor.

table.name: mem
table.column: "To win" a competition is {Qap:v:nolink}. If the victory is decisive or particularly gratifying, the expression {Qapchu':v:nolink} is used, even if it's a bit redundant.[4]

This is defined in {TKD:src} as "work, function, succeed", and in {KGT:src} as "win" and "operate, be in operation" (two separate entries). The "succeed" and "win" meanings are elaborated upon in {TKW:src}. In {HQ 2.4:src}, it is explained that to Klingons, to win is to function perfectly.
▶ {tlhIngan 'IH qaD DaQap.:sen:nolink} "Win Klingon beauty contest."[5] ▶ {qeylIS 'etlh Datlhapqa' 'e' DaQapbe'.:sen:nolink} "Fail to retrieve the Sword of Kahless."[5]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used as a ritual greeting.

table.name: mem
table.column: behave falsely honorably, behave in a falsely honorable manner

Deception is implied by the use of this verb. However, it differs from {toj:v} in that the deception involves honor or social status in some way. For example, this verb might be used of someone who claimed to be of a rank that he not had achieved, or to be a member of a house or family to which he did not belong.
behave falsely honourably, behave in a falsely honourable manner

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the verb (or adjective) meaning "to be good". For "good" as an exclamation expressing satisfaction, see {maj:excl}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The meaning of this word is like {negh:n}, but it excludes officers ({yaS:n}). The highest ranks of {QaS:n:1,nolink} are: ▶ {bu':n} "sergeant" ▶ {Da':n} "corporal"
It's possible that this word can be used to refer to a single troop member.[2, p.51]
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {tlhIngan QaS:n:nolink} is the unit of currency used in the game. From this game, we have the examples {"GO" DajuSDI' cha'vatlh QaS yItlhap:sen:nolink} and {wa'vatlh QaS yItlhap:sen:nolink}. Note that the singular prefix {yI-:v} is used even though {QaS:n:1,nolink} is an inherently plural noun whose members are being counted.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: He appeared in the episode {TOS - Friday's Child:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: For "hard (not soft)", see {let:v}. See also {ngem Sarghmey tlha':sen:idiom} for an idiom related to difficulty or complexity.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is listed erroneously as a noun in {TKD:src} in both word lists, but is described as a verb on p.49. It is also used in {TKW:src} on p.211 as a verb.

▶ {nuQaw'qu'be'.} "They have not finished us off."[1] ▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2] ▶ {not Soj QaQ Qaw' tlhInganpu'.} "Klingons never destroy good food.[3]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: blow one's top, lose one's temper
See {Qay':v:2} (def'n 2) for a related idiomatic expression.
In {TKD:src} this is defined as "blow one's top".[1] In {HQ 10.2:src}, the additional definition "lose one's temper" was added for clarification.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiomatic expression {'oy'qu' Qay'wI'wIj.:sen} This literally means "my little toe aches a lot", but it carries the idiomatic meaning "I'm extremely angry." The expression undoubtedly arose due to the homophony between {Qay':v:2,nolink} "use the little toe" and {Qay':v:1} "blow one's top".

table.name: mem
table.column: More specifically, this animal is called the {jajlo' Qa':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word element appears to be synonymous with {DIvI':n}, but it is not known outside of a few compounds.

table.name: mem
table.column: Krada legs are a popular Klingon food made from the extremities of a krada.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of animal (similar to {Qa':n:1}, but smaller)
This does not make a ruckus at dawn, unlike the {jajlo' Qa':n}. It is mistaken for a bird by some.[1]

This word appears in the "Curses" section of the {KCD:src} Language Lab. In the introduction to the holodeck part of the game, it is used in a derogatory manner to describe someone who is weak and scares easily.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears as {QeD patmey noch patmey je:n:nolink} "science and remote sensing systems".

table.name: mem
table.column: value, cherish, prize, hold to be precious?

This word is known only from these sentences from {Klingon Monopoly:src}: {Qo'noS romuluS je boSuqlaH. vabDot tera' Qejbogh DIvI' ram boSuqlaH.:sen:nolink} "Kronos, Romulus and even the puny Federation's precious Earth, are all up for grabs."

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the general word for a "doctor" or "physician". A doctor who performs surgery is a {HaqwI':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: hole (like a hole in the ground)
This can be used for a hole in the ground, a hollow in a tree, and so on. The difference between a {QemjIq:n:nolink} and a {qung:n} is that the former can be filled ({teb:v}).
In the Beatles song "A Day in The Life", a line goes "Four thousand holes in Blackburn, Lancashire".

table.name: mem
table.column: ground-up, dried-up mixture for brewing tea
This refers to the dried tea brew including plants or animal parts. For the drink made from this, see {Dargh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: any gas produced by a body

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {yIQeqQo' neH. DoS yIqIp!:sen}[2] ▶ {'ay'vamDaq nuHmey tIQeq.:sen:nolink} "Target weapons on this location."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to heat meat in animal's blood and condiments.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for the command deck of a ship (also called a "bridge" in English) is {meH:n}.
This is a reference to the novel "The Bridge over the River Kwai" ("Le Pont de la Rivière Kwai") by Pierre Boulle.

table.name: mem
table.column: Do not confuse this word with {SoQ:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of literary style.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a hand-held device, pressed up against an adversary.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word also refers to the sharpened end of a pencil. It likely refers to the sharp end of any stick-like object.

table.name: mem
table.column: plain spearhead with single sharp point

table.name: mem
table.column: It may have any number of points, not just five.

table.name: mem
table.column: In some early versions of {TNK:src}, "postcard" was translated as {ngeHmeH QIn nav:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "kris" or "keris" is a type of wavy-bladed knife found in Southeast Asia.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a volcano on {Qo'noS:n}, where legend says {qeylIS:n:name} dipped a lock of his hair to forge the first {betleH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any military organization. The official Klingon {QI':n} is the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {PK:src}, this is pronounced by Michael Dorn like {Qetlop:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of an outpost in the Klingon Empire near the Romulan border, where an important peace agreement was signed with the Federation.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Paradise (source of creation in Klingon mythology)
There are two idioms associated with {QI'tu':n:nolink}, both to do with its age: {ngo'; QI'tu' rur} and {qan; QI'tu' rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Klingon Empire, at one point colonized by Klingons.
It may or may not be a coincidence that the name of this planet appears to be made up of {QI':n} and {yoS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Disagreement is also expressed by the idiomatic expression {cha' DoSmey DIqIp.:sen:idiom}

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word refers to the organ. For the sense of "mind", see {yab:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb refers to the idea of war. For concrete fighting, see {ghob:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be hazardous, be perilous, be treacherous

table.name: mem
table.column: A message on {msn:src} dated 1997.06.18 explains the etymology of {QongDaq:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons do not lie in bed.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz said that this means "bed pouch", and perhaps a sleeping bag is {QongDaq buq'a':n:nolink} and a pillow is {QongDaq buqHom:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This term does not appear as such in canon, but {QongmeH qItI'nga' Duj:n:nolink} appears as the translation of "a sleeper ship of this [K'Tinga] class" in {SkyBox 15:src}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any music, whether vocal or instrumental or both.[2]
This sounds like the Cantonese word for "song".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This may be shortened to just {jan:n:2} if the context is clearly musical, but this is seldom done.[1]
Types of Klingon musical instruments include: percussion ({'In:n}), wind (no overall term), windbag or bellows ({SuSDeq:n}), and stringed ({HurDagh:n}). Wind instruments include the {Dov'agh:n}, the {gheb:n}, and the {meSchuS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v:nolink}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The hunter does not lie down with the prey.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a leader who conquered neighbouring areas of his region.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This region is named after Krotmag ({Qotmagh:n:name}).
In the Krotmag region, speakers replace {b:sen:nolink} with {m:sen:nolink} and {D:sen:nolink} with {N:sen:nolink}.[1, p.21]
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: Be careful not to say this word by accident if you mean {Hotlh:v} instead.[2]
{QaptaHvIS So'wI', Hoch jagh Dujmey DaQotlh.:sen:nolink} "Disable all enemy ships while cloaked."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
This word does not appear in the word lists in {TKD:src}, but appears in the explanation of {-moH:v:suff} in {TKD 4.2.4:src}, where {chenmoH:v} also appears. This entry is here for ease of reference.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The actors who performed this song on {KCD:src} mispronounced the first word of the fourth line {Say'moHchu':v:nolink} as {SeymoHchu':v:nolink}.
The line {yoHbogh matlhbogh je SuvwI':sen:nolink} is not a mistake, but a deliberately poetic or archaic usage, which is mirrored by the English "warrior brave and true". In standard Klingon, it would be {yoHbogh 'ej matlhbogh SuvwI':sen:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: no, I won't, I refuse, I disagree
