{TKD:src} lists this as "no, I won't, I refuse", and {TKDA:src} adds "no, I disagree".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tlhIngan wo' yuQmey chovlu'chugh Qo'noS potlh law' Hoch potlh puS. roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH. pa' 'oHtaH vaS'a''e'. tlhIngan qum waw' 'oH. yoq yIn yuQ 'oH Qo'noS'e'. yInSIp voQSIp je ngaS muDDaj.:sen:nolink} "The principal planet of the Klingon Empire, Qo'noS is usually referred to as simply "The Homeworld." This is where the Klingon Great Hall is located, the center of the Klingon government. Qo'noS is a class-M planet with an oxygen/nitrogen atmosphere."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
The slang meaning of {chong:v:2,slang}, when applied to a person, is equivalent to {Qubchu'} "think clearly".[3]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vIQub.:sen:nolink} "I think that you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Regional words for forehead include: {boD:n}, {jargh:n}, {mIQ:n}, {'aQlo':n}, {Huy'Dung:n}, {tuqvol:n}, and {no''och:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not mean exactly the same thing as {'IQ:v}, since it implies a change from being happy to not being happy.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The difference between this and {reH:v} is that this refers to structured play, whereas {reH:v:nolink} refers to unstructured play.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word means "ball" in the sense of a spherical object for playing.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {QujwI' lIw:n:nolink} is used to refer to the game pieces that stand in for the player.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: {Sam:v} is probably better for this sense of "find" than {tu':v}, but that's how the sentence appears on {TKD p.171:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Little is known about the Klingon gods, except that it seems they acted collectively, and no single individual stood out from among them. {Qun'a':n:nolink} may or may not be an appropriate translation for the supreme deity of a monotheistic religion, since the {Qun'a':n:nolink} would still be one among many.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not mean a building ({qach:n}) or a collection of people or states ({DIvI':n}, {tlham:n:slang}), but rather the way things fit together or the arrangement of the parts of something bigger. It can be used to mean "anatomy" when referring to animals.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can only refer to physically supporting something. It cannot be used for psychological or any other non-physical type of support. The word {ghaq:v} is used for monetary support.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: {jol Quv yIchegh.:sen:nolink} "Return to the transport site."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: May your coordinates be free of tribbles!

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary of {Enemy Territory:src}, this animal prefers the shadow.

table.name: mem
table.column: Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchugh, qoj matlhHa'chugh, pagh ghaH SuvwI''e'.
If a warrior ignores duty, acts dishonorably, or is disloyal, he is nothing.
If a warrior ignores duty, acts dishonourably, or is disloyal, he is nothing.

table.name: mem
table.column: When you begin a mission, remember Aktuh and Melota.

table.name: mem
table.column: Qu'Daj ta'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.
To die in the line of duty is the hope of every Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingon curse, said in moments of extreme anger
In a deleted scene from {Star Trek V:src}, the response to this curse was an invective in Klingon followed by the English "Screw you too!"

table.name: mem
table.column: When this verb is applied to living beings, it suggests an improvement in health. When it is applied to an inanimate object, it implies improvement or betterment. It is distinguished from {tI':v} because that verb is not usually applied to beings, and suggests a restoration to a previous state and not improvement. It also differs from {Dub:v} in that that verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no single term for "nurse" in Klingon. Other possible terms for a doctor's assistant are {Qel boQ:n:nolink} (or {HaqwI' boQ:n:nolink} if the doctor is a surgeon) and {QelHom:n:nolink}.[1]
Nurse "Ratch"ed, from "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of food made from live serpent worms (not to be confused with {qagh:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: Rajma is red kidney bean curry.

table.name: mem
table.column: be trivial, be trifling, be unimportant, be insignificant

table.name: mem
table.column: The opposite of this is {pem:n}, not {jaj:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Avian life-form indigenous to {Qo'noS:n} that only comes out in the dark.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject of {rap:v:nolink} are the things which are the same.[2]
This verb can also be used to express the concept that two things have the same amount of some quality. The verb {nIb:v} is used similarly, but it is usually used with measurable qualities and has the connotation of preciseness. However, it is not improper to use {rap:v:nolink} with a quality that is measurable. See the example below.[3]
▶ {ghun 'Iw HIq, rap boqrat chej.} "The bokrat liver is as warm as the bloodwine."[3] ▶ {'ey ro'qegh'Iwchab, rap qagh.} "The gagh is as delicious as the rokeg blood pie."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of the actress who plays B'Elanna Torres.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to weapons or spaceships. See {KGT p.79:src} for an explanation of this verb.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that each floor, or level, on a vessel is called a {choQ:n} (deck).
There is a Klingon idiom, {'IQ; rav rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Hung buv rav; patlh Hut:sen:nolink} "Classified Level 9 and Above"[1] ▶ {nen rav; chorgh ben:sen:nolink} "Ages 8 to adult"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to the ceiling of a room that has a room above it. The ceiling of a room which is on the top (or only) story of a structure is called its {pa' beb:n}.[2]
According to a message on the {s.k:src} newsgroup, the first element of this word is {rav:n:1} "floor", but the second element is unrelated to {'eq:v} "be early".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: an aquatic bird with colorful plumage

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call Terran rice.

table.name: mem
table.column: The High Command runs the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a drink made from liquor added to coffee. Its name may have originated as a contraction of {ra'wI' taj:n:nolink}. An "export" version called "raktajino", popular in the Federation, is not alcoholic, but has added flavour.[1, p.96]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to someone of rank {Sogh:n} or higher.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Retch". Also, the words for inhale and exhale together sound like "poor wretch" ({pur rech:sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Romulan Star Empire.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {tun; reghuluS 'Iwghargh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Sometimes, it may be appropriate to use {-taH:v:suff} (without {reH:adv}) to translate "always". For example, see {Duj tIvoqtaH.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: The difference between this and {Quj:v} is that this refers to unstructured play, whereas {Quj:v:nolink} refers to structured play.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: One is always of his tribe.

table.name: mem
table.column: The used kut'luch is always shiny.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your father is a part of you always.

table.name: mem
table.column: reH ghoblu'DI' yay quv law' Hoch quv puS.
In war, there is nothing more honorable than victory.
In war, there is nothing more honourable than victory.

table.name: mem
table.column: Always it is the brave ones who die.

table.name: mem
table.column: May you always find a bloodworm in your glass!

table.name: mem
table.column: reH latlh qabDaq qul tuj law' Hoch tuj puS.
The fire is always hotter on someone else's face.

table.name: mem
table.column: A Klingon warrior is always prepared to fight.

table.name: mem
table.column: A great warrior is always prepared.

table.name: mem
table.column: May the Klingon Empire continue forever.

table.name: mem
table.column: I will remember this dinner forever.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used to describe the design of a physical object of some sort; it would not be used in the sense of making a plan to do something (which would be {nab:v}). It differs from {'ogh:v}, which implies the creation of something which has not been created before.
Christopher Wren and James Renwick, Jr., were the names of two famous architects.

table.name: mem
table.column:
A specialised word is used to indicate a time in the past for the following units: ▶ {jaj:n} "day" - {Hu':n} "days ago" ▶ {jar:n} "month" - {wen:n} "months ago" ▶ {DIS:n:2} "year" - {ben:n:1} "years ago"
For other units of time, {ret:n:nolink} is used.

table.name: mem
table.column: To be more specific, one can use {tlhop:n}, {'em:n}, {poS:n}, or {nIH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the action of alternately squeezing and stretching out the bag part of the {may'ron:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: One first charges up ({Huj:v:2,t}) a device before energizing ({rIH:v:nolink}) it.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used by small children, or by adults talking to or about small children. Adults typically use {Sen:v} instead.
The reflexive form of this verb has a special meaning. See the example below, and under {SIq:v} for an explanation.
▶ {nujDajDaq rIl'egh ghu.:sen:nolink} "The baby sucks its thumb."

table.name: mem
table.column: The usage of this verb is restricted to the {gheb:n}, while {SuS:v} is a more general term that applies to all wind instruments.
{gheb rIl:sen:nolink} is a reference to the horn of Gabriel.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used by small children, or by adults talking to or about small children. Adults typically use {SenwI':n} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column:
By itself, {rIn:v:nolink} is used in radio transmissions to indicate end of transmission, similar to "over".
This verb is used with the suffix {-taH:v} to form {rIntaH:v}, a construction used to indicate finality (cf. the suffix {-ta':v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This special verbal construction follows another verb to indicate that the action described by the preceding verb is a fait accompli. It is similar in meaning to the verb suffix {-ta':v:suff}, but has the additional connotation of finality.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TKD:src} this is defined as "be injured". The "be damaged" extension of the meaning is from {Klingon Monopoly:src}.
▶ {Dumer DIvI' QaS 'ej DuHIv, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIrIQchoH.:sen:nolink} "Surprise attack by Federation leaves you unprotected and damaged."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: An obvious extension of this is {rItHa':v:nolink} for "dismiss".
{DurIt tlhIngan yejquv.:sen:nolink} "Summoned to the Klingon High Council."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no noun in Klingon meaning "color".[1, p.81]

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is not known to exist outside of {yInroH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is considered too potent for tourists.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {matlhHa'; romuluSngan rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {HoHwI':n} for short.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In the context of aircraft attitude, {HQ 11.2:src} glosses this word as "aircraft wings tilt, one up, one down". (For a pilot to roll an aircraft would be {ronmoH:v:nolink}.)
In the context of playing dice, this word refers to the action of the dice as they are rolling. (To "throw" or "roll" the dice would be {ronmoH:v:nolink}.)
The aile"ron"s control the roll on an airplane.

table.name: mem
table.column: be agile, be nimble, be spry?
This verb is not known to exist, but its existence is conjectured based on the idiom {pe'vIl roS:sen:idiom} and the verb {roSHa'moH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {HQ 10:src}.2, this verb consists of three elements: the verb {roS:v:3,is,hyp}, {-Ha':v}, and {-moH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression is used to challenge someone to take action in a manner consistent with something he or she just said. (It's similar to the English expression "put your money where your mouth is".)

table.name: mem
table.column: In the glossary to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, it is hypothesized that this is an animal from or with whose blood {ro'qegh'Iwchab:n} are made.

table.name: mem
table.column: {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: From the children's rhyme, a teapot is "short" ({run:v}) and "stout" ({pI':v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The gas produced is called {SIp:n} or {Qep'It:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a city in {ghevchoq Sep:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used to form similes, such as {puj verengan; bIQ rur} "the Ferengi is as weak as water".[2; 4] It can also be used to translate "like" in the sense of "looks like".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon penal colony, a planet mostly covered in ice. Prisoners are sent to work in its {tlhIlHalmey:n:nolink} (see {tlhIlHal:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: He can sell ice on Rura Penthe.

table.name: mem
table.column: This describes a bond such as exists between blood brothers.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ritual that allows an orphan to join another House.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "sometimes" in {TKD:src} and as "occasionally" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be ready to collapse or die (referring to food)
This is an upper-class word to describe food that should be eaten live.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is also spelled {SanID:n:nolink}.
Note that Klingon has words for "ten thousand" ({netlh:n:num}) and "hundred thousand" ({bIp:n:num}) which are independent of the word for "thousand".

table.name: mem
table.column: To indicate "millenia ago" or "millenia from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chobelHa'moH, DI'qar. SajlIj 'oHbe' quvwIj'e'.:sen:nolink} "You disappoint me, D'Kar. My honor is not your play-thing."[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: See the example for an illustration of the difference between this word and {nej:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {chenmoH:v} can be used with {San:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: land; set down on land (like a bird)
If a bird lands on a tree, the verb {ngun:v} is used, and if on water, then {tlhot:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the native region of Kahless the Unforgettable on {Qo'noS:n:place}, and the location of his estate.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons have no tear ducts, and there is no word for tear or tears. However, Klingons eyes do redden ({DoqchoH:v:nolink}) from time to time.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be shallow, be superficial, be uncritical; be unfortunate, be not good
This word is applied to a person to disparage his or her intellect. It is also used by itself as an expression of disapproval, similar to {Do'Ha'.:sen}[1, p.164]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was revealed during a session of singing and dancing the Hokey Pokey.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a large region several thousand kilometers east of the First City ({veng wa'DIch:n}). In the dialect of this region, prepositionals take suffixes (see under {lurgh:n} for an explanation). Furthermore, toasts follow the normal word order, with the subject following the verb (see {-jaj:v}).
This region contains {HuD beQ yoS:n}.

This is basically "jackass" spelled backwards.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Segh - bI'rel tlharghDuj:sen:nolink} "Model - B'rel Scout"[2] ▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears to consist of {SeH:v} (or a homophonous element) and the otherwise unattested {law:n:hyp,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: {leng Dotlh SeHwI' pat:n}, {muD ngeb SeHwI' pat:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: Small children, or adults talking to or about small children, use {rIl:v:1} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: Small children, or adults talking to or about small children, use {rIlwI':n} instead.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {let mInDu'Daj; Separmey rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be formal, be ritualistic, be ceremonial

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to music.[2, p.71]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is composed of {Se':n} and {tu':v}, which suggests that Klingons believe Terran saucepans to be satellite dishes. According to the explanation by qe'San, this was apparently based on "set-to" because there was a heated discussion about it.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a publication of any kind, whether printed or not.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a pun on the name of a well-known Terran publishing house.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device used for two-way communication. For the device which receives (but does not send) an audio signal, see {wab HevwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: {chaw'vam yIpol 'ej SIbI'Ha' yIlo' pagh 'oH yImech.} "This card may be kept until needed or traded."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: When used in the slang sense, this verb does not take an object.[1, p.164]

table.name: mem
table.column: type of knife (used for food preparation)
This is used for finer work in cooking.

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {boq:v} for the basic mathematical operations.

table.name: mem
table.column:
When used with nouns marked with {-Daq:n}, the finger verbs mean "point (with that finger) at or towards" the object indicated by that noun.
There are some special cases of the reflexive (with {-'egh:v}) forms of the finger verbs. See the example below, and also under {rIl:v:1}.
If an implement is used for an activity typically performed by a finger, a finger verb may be used.

▶ {maghwI'Daq jISIq.:sen:nolink} "I point at the traitor with my index finger." ▶ {ghIchwIj vISIq.:sen:nolink} "I touch my nose with my index finger." ▶ {ghIchwIjDaq jISIq:sen:nolink} "I point at my nose with my index finger." ▶ {ghIchwIjDaq jISIq'egh.:sen:nolink} "I pick my nose with my index finger." ▶ {maghwI'Daq SIq naQjejwIj.:sen:nolink} "My spear points at the traitor."

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons use {SIQ:v:nolink} rather than {tIv:v} for some things that humans might consider pleasant or neutral.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take an object. Its subject is usually unstated.[2]
It's the sound of rain falling.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not known to exist outside of the compound {SIS yoD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object. When used as the second verb in a sentence as object construction, it is usually translated as "wonder if".[2]
This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}, probably as a joke to make us wonder if it was a mistake.
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vISIv.:sen:nolink} "I wonder if you speak Klingon." This means something like, "I am curious about whether you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: seventh tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2,nolink}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: May the spirit of Kahless live within you.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word applies to both food and beverages[2], or anything consumed for sustenance.[5] A single dish or course is called a {nay':n}.[2]
This word carries the idiomatic meaning of "matter, concern, affair". For example, {tlhIngan Soj 'oH; not bIyaj:sen:nolink} means "It is a Klingon matter -- you'll never understand."[3]

▶ {yIntaHbogh tlhIngan Soj tlhol jablu'DI' tIvqu'lu'. qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink} "Klingon food is best when served fresh and live. Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is rare unless meal was interrupted.[1, p.102]

table.name: mem
table.column: Of course, {Soj naQmey:n} are always used in pairs.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a food storage room.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is usually served only on the most formal occasions.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb to use for compiling such a list is {gher:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to food that no one has done anything to.[1, p.84]

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear whether this verb is used for the relief of pain, anxiety, distress, etc., or for the removal of someone from active duty. If it is used for the latter, then it is related in meaning to {cho':v} and {gheS:v}, and perhaps it also forms the first part of {SonchIy:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremony which either precedes or is the initial part of the Rite of Succession (see {cho'tay:n:hyp}).
Perhaps this word is related to {Son:v} and {che':v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a typo for {Suq:v:nolink} which appeared in {HQ 6.2:src} in the transcription of {SkyBox 33:src}. The word is spelled correctly as {Suq:v:nolink} on the card itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: Do not confuse this word with {QIch:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {lugh; Sor rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: One kind of {Sor Hap 'In:n} is a tube which is open on both ends, with a longitudinal slit which doesn't go all the way to either end, and which is struck with a {mupwI'Hom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The siblings of a {SoS:n} are {me':n} and {'IrneH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vISov.:sen:nolink} "I know that you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, this word is used instead of {ghIH:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: If there is no object, then the subject is the one hiding (e.g., {nuqDaq So'taH yaS?:sen:nolink}). If there is an object, then the subject is hiding the object (e.g., {Duj So':sen:nolink} or {Duj So'lu'pu':sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: On {SkyBox 33:src}, the last two Klingon sentences were not translated into English: "A cloaking device which didn't disrupt weaponry was installed in one experimental ship. This ship was demonstrated on Stardate 9521.6 but it was destroyed."

table.name: mem
table.column: be brave, be heroic, be bold, be valient, be intrepid

table.name: mem
table.column: "Sub" is the opposite of "super" as in "superhero".

table.name: mem
table.column: The German verb for "to visit" is "besuchen".
▶ {vogh vISuch vIneH.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit some place."[2] ▶ {loHwI' vISuch 'e' vIpoQ!:sen:nolink} "I demand to see the magistrate!"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v} and {SuD:v:1,nolink}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

table.name: mem
table.column: gamble, take a chance, take a risk

table.name: mem
table.column: The literal meaning of this idiomatic expression is "Fek'lhr's eyes are green".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is also written as {Su':excl:nolink}. Some speakers of Klingon pronounce this word as if it were {SSS:excl:nolink}.
This exclamation indicates that the speaker is about to give a command, or is ready to do something or that arrangements have been made for something to happen. ({TKD 5.5:src})

table.name: mem
table.column:
The use of this word involves the concept of deixis. It usually implies the subject is near the speaker, unless the context is set up to indicate the action is taking place somewhere else (for example, using {-Daq:v}). The suffix {-chuq:v} is not used with this verb.[2]
The expression {jISum:sen:nolink} has an idiomatic philosophical meaning, "I'm in touch with my inner self" (in a Klingon way).[2]
▶ {yuQ SumDaq cha'puj law' Datu'.} "Detect large sums of dilithium on nearby planet."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Sup"erman can jump higher than a building.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word "ukelele" means "jumping flea" in Hawaiian.

table.name: mem
table.column: prepare kud in a specific way

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not known to exist by itself, but appears to be one of the components of {Surchem:n}, with {chem:n:hyp}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It sounds like the wind blowing.

table.name: mem
table.column: blow (into wind instrument) to produce sound
This is a general term which is applied to all wind instruments, while {rIl:v:2} is restricted to the {gheb:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a category of musical instruments with a flexible bag which is alternately filled with and emptied of air. The sound is produced by the air passing over strips of material which vibrate (see {joQ:n:1}). Known types of {SuSDeq:n:nolink} include the {may'ron:n} and the {DIron:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The afterlife for the honored dead, where all true warriors go after they die to fight an eternal battle. The closest Klingon equivalent to heaven.
Used by DeCandido in 2001 novel Diplomatic Implausibility; confirmed by MO at {qep'a' 2010:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bISuv 'e' yIwIv; bISutlh 'e' yIwIvQo'.:sen} ▶ {bISutlhnISchugh jaghlI' mInDu' tIbej.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: If a warrior does not fight, he does not breathe.

table.name: mem
table.column: Brute strength is not the most important asset in a fight.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons are born to fight and to conquer.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a specific warrior. For warriorhood as concept, see {vaj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Calling someone a {Suy':n:nolink} is considered insulting, comparable to calling someone a "pig" in Federation Standard.[1, p.196]
"Sooey" is a sound used in calling pigs. The Hog Call, a traditional cheer at the University of Arkansas, goes "Woo, Pig! Sooey!"

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, sugar (common table sugar) is translated as {Su'ghar qutmey:n:nolink}. Presumably, then, a single {Su'ghar qut:n:nolink} would be one grain of sugar.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is partially digested and used as a sauce called {quD:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: We will meet in the cocktail lounge.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word also has the idiomatic sense of "don't move!" when given as a command, either as {yItaD:sen:nolink} (spoken to one person) or {petaD:sen:nolink} (spoken to a group of people).[2]
According to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, {taD:n:place,fic,nolink} is the name of an ice-covered colony planet in the Klingon Empire.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject of this verb is the person or thing starting the process, and the object is the process. For example: {Qu' DataghDI' 'aqtu' mellota' je tIqaw.:sen} "When you begin a mission, remember Aktuh and Mellota."[2]
If the starter of the process is unknown, unclear, or indefinite, the process becomes the subject of the verb (in which case it takes no object): {taghbej mu'qaD veS:sen:nolink} "Curse-warfare has definitely begun."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tagha' pawpu' meb 'ach pumDI' Heghpu' qagh.:sen:nolink} "The guest finally arrived, but by then the gagh had died."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: earlier than expected, initially, at first?
This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column:
The residents of this region greatly outnumber the residents of {Qotmagh Sep:n}.
This dialect is sort of half-way between the standard dialect and the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect. Speakers replace {b:sen:nolink} with {mb:sen:nolink} and {D:sen:nolink} with {ND:sen:nolink}.[1, p.22]

This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.22 and not in the glossary. It appears as {taq'ev:n:nolink} and not as {taq'ev Sep:n:nolink}, but it is implied that this is the name of a region (see {Sep:n}).

table.column: The Tasman Sea separates Australia from New Zealand, and is colloquially called "the Ditch".

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb means to return something somewhere, for example a weapon to the weapons rack. To express the concept of returning to a place, use {chegh:v}.[1]
{raSDaq jengva' vItatlh.:sen:nolink} "I return the plate to the table."[1]

▶ {pa'Daq jItatlh'egh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the room." The implication here is that it is difficult or not desirable to return to the room.[1]

Note that a human ({Human:n}) is a member of the major indigenous language-capable species of Earth ({tera':n:place}), whereas Terran ({tera'ngan:n:nolink}) refers to any inhabitant of the planet.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This term is used in the invitation to {Star Trek The Exhibition:src}. The invitation reads: ▶ {tera' poH jaj wa', jar wa', jaj loSDIch, DIS wa'-Hut-Hut-chorgh. HovpoHvetlh latlh nab yIHutlh.:sen:nolink} "Save this Stardate: Sunday, January 4, 1998".[1]
Based on the information on the invitation, when telling an Earth date: ▶ {jaj:n} followed by a number labels the day of the week, starting with Sunday, which is {jaj wa':n:nolink}; ▶ {jar:n} followed by a number labels the month, starting with January, {jar wa':n:nolink}; ▶ the day of the month is given as an ordinal, {jaj loSDIch:n:nolink} "the fourth day"; ▶ the year is specified by giving its digits after the word {DIS:n:2}.[1] However, the numbering of Sunday as "day one" may have been to cater to Americans.[2]
If the pattern holds, then the days of the week are: ▶ {jaj wa':n:nolink} "Sunday" ▶ {jaj cha':n:nolink} "Monday" ▶ {jaj wej:n:nolink} "Tuesday" ▶ {jaj loS:n:nolink} "Wednesday" ▶ {jaj vagh:n:nolink} "Thursday" ▶ {jaj jav:n:nolink} "Friday" ▶ {jaj Soch:n:nolink} "Saturday"
Similarly, the Terran months are: ▶ {jar wa':n:nolink} "January" ▶ {jar cha':n:nolink} "February" ▶ {jar wej:n:nolink} "March" ▶ {jar loS:n:nolink} "April" ▶ {jar vagh:n:nolink} "May" ▶ {jar jav:n:nolink} "June" ▶ {jar Soch:n:nolink} "July" ▶ {jar chorgh:n:nolink} "August" ▶ {jar Hut:n:nolink} "September" ▶ {jar wa'maH:n:nolink} "October" ▶ {jar wa'maH wa':n:nolink} "November" ▶ {jar wa'maH cha':n:nolink} "December"
Terran date, Terran time, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, January, February, March, April, May, June, July, August, September, October, November, December

table.name: mem

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the organ of hearing inside the head, while {qogh:n:2,body} refers to the external flap of skin, cartilage, etc.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to one's mother's sister's child or one's father's brother's child (i.e., "parallel cousins").

table.name: mem
table.column: A female {tey':n}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's sister's child or one's father's brother's child, or a niece in the sense of a man's brother's daughter or a woman's sister's daughter.

table.name: mem
table.column: A male {tey':n}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's sister's son or one's father's brother's son, or nephew in the sense of a man's brother's son or a woman's sister's son.

table.column: This is the midway point between the cardinal directions {tIng:n} and {'ev:n}. It is also referred to as {'ev tIng:n:nolink} with about the same frequency.[1] It is 270 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.

table.column: Real power is in the heart.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In {Klingon Academy:src}, the symbol of the Klingon Empire (the imperial trefoil) is said to be called the "Heart of Virtue", or {tIq'ghob:n:nolink} "in the ancient tongue", by General Chang ({cheng:n:name}). In modern standard Klingon, "Heart of Virtue" would be {ghob tIq:n:nolink}. The two words are transposed in the manner of {paq'batlh:n}.
The three arms of the {tIq'ghob:n:nolink} are said to represent honor, loyalty, and duty.

The eleva"tor"s control the pitch on an airplane.

▶ {to'waQ yIyIv.:sen:nolink} "Take your time thinking about it." ▶ {to'waQ vIyIvtaH.:sen:nolink} "I'm in the process of taking my time considering the matter." ▶ {to'waQ yIyIvQo', DaH yIwuq!:sen:nolink} "Don't chew ligament, decide now!"

table.name: mem
table.column:
To say "Kahlor of the House of Molor", one simply says {qeylor, molor tuq:sen:nolink} "Kahlor, House of Molor". To be more formal, one can add the father's name, as in {qeylor, qeylIn puqloD, molor tuq:sen:nolink} "Kahlor, son of Kahlin, (of the) House of Molor".[2]
Another formal and slightly archaic way to express membership in a House is to use the verb {tay':v}: ▶ {tay' qeylor molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "Kahlor is of the House of Molor" ▶ {matay' jIH molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "I am of the House of Molor" ▶ {Sutay' SoH molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "You are of the House of Molor" This construction seems to be related to the proverb {reH tay' ghot tuqDaj je.:sen}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {tuq:n} for an explanation of how to express membership in a House.

table.name: mem

table.name: mem

Note that "there are" is {lutu'lu':sen:nolink} (see {lu-:v}), but for unknown reasons the {lu-:v} prefix is sometimes dropped.

table.column: When used with the suffix {-qa':v}, the result has the sense of "retrieve".

▶ {jagh Duj DaQaw' 'ach pagh qama' Datlhapqa'.:sen:nolink} "Destroy enemy vessel without retrieving prisoners."[2] ▶ {qeylIS 'etlh Datlhapqa' 'e' DaQapbe'.:sen:nolink} "Fail to retrieve the Sword of Kahless."[2]

table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v:nolink}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

In the E-K word list of {TKD:src}, this was erroneously tagged as a noun.

▶ {Dargh vItlhutlhDI' mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink}; or {Dargh vItlhutlh. mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink}; or {Dargh vItlhutlh 'ej mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink} "I drink tea with Torg and Maltz."[2] ▶ {bIQongtaHvIS nItlhejchugh targhmey bIvemDI' nItlhej ghIlab ghewmey.:sen}[3] ▶ {QotDI' gheD tlhejbe' wamwI'.:sen}[3] ▶ {'Iw HIq vItlhutlh. mutlhej ghaH.:sen:nolink} "He/she drinks bloodwine with me."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column:
The verb for laying a carpet is {vel:v}. The verb {mutlh:v}, when applied to a carpet, means to assemble it.
The word {tlhIm:n:nolink} is also used for a fabric wall hanging. A {tlhIm:n:nolink} has to cover something. A fabric displayed at the end of a pole would be a {joqwI':n}.
Finally, {tlhIm:n:nolink} can also be used for a blanket, though Klingons generally don't use blankets.
A "gelim" is a type of Persian carpet.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {A Good Day to Die:src}, this is made from something orange.

table.name: mem
table.column: klin zha, a popular board game
This is a game of strategy which has been compared to chess.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that this refers to a person or people. For the Klingon language, see {tlhIngan Hol:n}.
There is an idiom, {Hem; tlhIngan rur}.
▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen} ▶ {bogh tlhInganpu', SuvwI'pu' moj, Hegh.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is used to make a request, whereas {ghel:v} is used for asking a question.[3]
The object of this verb is the person of whom the request is made, or {'e':n:pro} referring to the action which is requested.
{lutlhob; naDevvo' vaS'a'Daq majaHlaH'a'?:sen:nolink} "They ask him, can we get to the Great Hall from here?"[4]

It is unclear if this means "to tire someone out" (see {Doy':v}), "to use something up completely" (see {natlh:v:1}), or (as in English) both.
Some people believe that this word means "to expel exhaust", based on its similarity to {tlhuH:v:1}, and that {ghImwI':n} was a mistake for {tlhuchwI':n:nolink}.

Drinking fake ale is better than drinking water.

table.column: fifth tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2,nolink}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.column: so, then, thus, in that case
Note that this is not a conjunction, but an adverbial.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the concept of warriorhood (e.g., "warrior spirit", and so on). To refer to a person who is a warrior, use {SuvwI':n}.

{vaj Duj DachIj.:sen:nolink} "You have strength of character."

table.name: mem

{vaj Duj DachIj.:sen:nolink} "You have strength of character."
