table.column: vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.
Shooting space garbage is no test of a warrior's mettle.

This is a backfit for the sentence, {vaj toDDujDaj ngeHbej DIvI'.} "That means the Federation will be sending a rescue ship of its own." Both sentences were spoken by Captain Klaa in {Star Trek V:src}.
The original line was to have been {logh veQDaq bachchugh, yoH 'e' toblaHbe' SuvwI'.}

table.name: mem
table.column: end (an event, voyage, battle, play, opera, story, song, etc.)

The subject of this verb is the person causing an event to end. The object is the event that is ended. If the event was prematurely brought to an end, use {ghang:v} instead. To describe the ending of a period of time, use {Dor:v:2} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Gamma Quadrant.

table.name: mem
table.column: vangDI' tlhIngan SuvwI' ngoy' qorDu'Daj; vangDI' qorDu'Daj ngoy' tlhIngan SuvwI'.
The family of a Klingon warrior is responsible for his actions, and he is responsible for theirs.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bI'reS qeylIS vaq molor:sen:nolink} "First, Molor taunts Kahless"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be aggressive, be effective, be vigorous
This word was originally used in describing weapons, but is now also applied to people. It has strongly positive connotations in slang.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the seat of the Klingon government.

▶ {juHqo'Daq vaS'a' tu'lu'. ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'. DaH che' ghawran. yejquv DevwI' moj ghawran 'e' wuqta' cho' 'oDwI' Dapu'bogh janluq pIqarD HoD.:sen:nolink} "On the Homeworld, there is a great hall where the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire. Gowron currently presides, named leader of the High Council by Captain Jean-Luc Picard, who was acting as Arbiter of Succession."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: {cha'maH vagh vatlhvI' Hong, QIt yIghoS.:sen:nolink} "Slow to one quarter impulse."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: To indicate "centuries ago" or "centuries from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[3]
The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

table.name: mem
table.column: The siblings of a {vav:n} are {tennuS:n} and {'e'mam:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v:nolink}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The plural of this word is {veDDIrmey:n:nolink} rather than {veDDIrDu':n:nolink}.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: go through (an open door, a tunnel, etc.)

This verb only means to go through an opening of some sort, and not "to traverse" (in the sense of "going through" a forest).[1] The object is the thing being gone through. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The text of {SkyBox 99:src} reads: ▶ {loS... qIb HeHDaq, 'u' SepmeyDaq Sovbe'lu'bogh lenglu'meH He ghoSlu'bogh retlhDaq 'oHtaH. HaDlu'meH, QuSlu'meH, SuDlu'meH lojmIt Da logh Hop Hut tengchaH. vaj loghDaq lenglaHtaH Humanpu'. veH Qav 'oH logh'e'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject does the covering, while the object is covered.
This verb is used to describe the laying of a carpet. The person who lays a carpet is called a {velwI':n:nolink} (despite the fact that the grammar suggests that {velwI':n:nolink} would refer to the carpet itself).
▶ {rav vel tlhIm.:sen:nolink} "The carpet covers the floor." ▶ {rav velmeH tlhIm lo'.:sen:nolink} "He lays the carpet on the floor."

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, the "Chancellor's Cane Replica" is referred to as {Qang naQ velqa':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bird that feeds almost exclusively on the serpent worm from which {qagh:n} is made. Klingons are not particularly fond of this bird.
An early bird catches the worm.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {qej; veqlargh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: You pay attention to your Fek'lhr and I will pay attention to mine.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your ship is a garbage scow.

table.name: mem
table.column: Ferengis are known for their greed, as reflected in the comparison {qur; verengan rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the Ferengi Homeworld, the primary planet in the Ferengi Alliance.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the vehicle that is docked.[3]
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, "Free Parking" is translated as {vergh 'ach DIlnISbe':sen:nolink}.
▶ {nuqDaq puH Duj vIvergh?:sen:nolink} "Where can I park the car?"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Contrast this with {noH:n}, which refers to a specific war.

table.name: mem
table.column: The meaning of this word is unclear. Its only known occurrences are {veymey puS neH chenmoHlu'pu':sen:nolink} "Limited Edition", {boSwI'vaD veyvam le' chenmoHlu':sen:nolink} "Collector's Edition", and {wa' tlhIngan QaS vey:n:nolink} "one pack of Klingon forces", all from {Klingon Monopoly:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to me".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a device that regulates the flow of gas, sound, etc.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of animal, v'gro (like a cat)
"Figuro" is the name of the cat in Disney's Pinocchio.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is intransitive. To say that someone or something moves someone or something else, use {vIHmoH:v:nolink}.[2]
For an idiomatic expression used to tell someone not to move, see {taD:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression means that an activity of finite (though perhaps indeterminate) length has started.
{bISop DaneH'a'? vIHtaH gho.:sen:nolink} "If you want to eat, say so now before the food is gone."

table.name: mem
table.column: someone or something who is just there; someone who is around when you are
When this word was defined at {qep'a' 2009:src}, a description of an object which was recognised as a "speed bump" was given as an example of a {vIl:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The suggestion was made at {qep'a' 2009:src} that a {vIlHom:n:nolink} could be a single ridge in a {Quch:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bird capable of mimicking speech. Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the singular, typically {tey':n:nolink} or {lor:n:nolink} is preferred unless the individual is being referred to as a member of a group that likely includes both {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}. The plural form {vInpu':n:nolink} is used for a group that includes {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}.
A reference to the movie "My Cousin Vinny".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the abstract concept of combat. A specific battle is a {may':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's not clear whether this is a noun or a verb.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is any liquid from a plant. In some regional dialects, this word is used for any liquid accompanying food.
"V8" is a juice blend made from tomato juice mixed with the juices of various vegetables.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is intransitive; that is, it means "to be accumulated" rather than "to accumulate (something)". See the example.

table.name: mem
table.column: {cha' vI' vagh choQmey lutoghlu':sen:nolink} "Number of Decks: 2.5" {BoP:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to meat prepared by {HaH:v:2}. The word for the specific meat replaces the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be the object of {wel:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote how many {QaS:n:1} the player receives for mortgaging a planet to the bank.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to Captain "von Trapp" from The Sound of Music, who was played by Christopher Plummer, who of course was also General Chang ({cheng:n:name}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang term is not used in reference to games, but is applied only to more serious matters.[1, p.165]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears to consist of the verb {voQ:v} (or a homophonous but unknown noun) and {SIp:n}, so it means something like "choking gas".

table.name: mem
table.column: {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear why Federation Standard corrupted the spelling of this word by moving the {qaghwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: {QIStaq qul bIQtIqHomDaq 'etlhDaj vo' nuch:sen:nolink} "The coward throws his sword into the fire streams of Kri'stak"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Cowards take hostages. Klingons do not.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
Vulcans are also sometimes called Vulcanians in English.[2]
Note that this is {vulqangan:n:nolink} and not {vulqanngan:n:nolink} (the {n:sen:nolink} at the end of {vulqan:n:nolink} is dropped).
There is a Klingon idiom, {nong; vulqangan rur}, which is meant ironically.

table.name: mem
table.column: cook, prepare food, make a beverage
The definition in {TKD:src} is just "cook". On {KGT p.83:src}, this is expanded to include the preparation of any food, including beverages. Reverse of {tuv:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a place where food is prepared.

table.name: mem
table.column: The names of the Klingon consonants consist of the sound followed by {ay:sen:nolink}, and the names of the vowels consist of the sound preceded by {':sen:nolink} and followed by {t:sen:nolink}. The glottal stop is an exception, being called {qaghwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device that receives (but does not send) an audio signal. For the device used for two-way communication, see {Se' HablI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a more general meaning of {waH:v:2} (def'n 2).

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a specialized meaning of {waH:v:1} (def'n 1). It means to try out food to see if it's been properly prepared or to determine if one likes it.[2]
Do not confuse this with {mum:v}, which means "taste" in the sense of perceiving flavors.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is meat prepared with {ngat:n:2}. The word for the specific meat replaces the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an Indo-European root "wanha" with exactly this meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: You can certainly "wack" someone with it.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bird with a very long beak.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of knife (used for food preparation)
This is large, sharp, and square-bladed, almost like an {'obmaQ:n}.
This is a reference to Ward and June Cleaver, from the television show "Leave It to Beaver". See {tlher:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the mathematical operation of division, see {boqHa''egh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: We succeed together in a greater whole.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "we hit one target". It can be shortened to just {DoS wIqIp.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: wa' jaj 'etlh 'uchchoHlaH tlhIngan puqloD; jajvetlh loD nen moj.
The son of a Klingon is a man the day he can first hold a blade.

table.name: mem
table.column: For one mission, there is one leader.

table.name: mem
table.column: wa' SuvwI' muHlu'DI', tuHchoH Hoch SuvwI'pu'.
The execution of but one warrior brings shame to all.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Quj wa'DIch:n:nolink} is used to refer to the original Monopoly game. So {wa'DIch:n:nolink} can be used for "original" in the sense of "the first" (see under {qa':v} for the sentence).

table.name: mem
table.column: wa'maH cha' pemmey wa'maH cha' rammey je

This idiomatic expression refers to an event in the life of Kahless the Unforgettable, when he fought his brother Morath for twelve days and twelve nights (as recounted in the {paq'batlh:src}). The expression means not only that the length of the event is long, but also that the event is an important one, worthy of taking up so much time.

table.name: mem
table.column: serve fermented food at its peak
This is food mixed with {'atlhqam:n}, fermented, and served.[1, p.92]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is like {yot:v}, but with the connotation of surprise or speed.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: A warrior fights to the death.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing owed, but the prefix trick can also be used, in which case the object is the person to whom something is owed.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has this meaning in the {voSpegh Sep:n} dialect.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ship's full complement of personnel, crew plus officers.

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to us".

table.name: mem
table.column: be sour, be bitter, be tart
{Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {wIH; Hur'Iqngan rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an expression used between close friends in the higher social classes. It should be avoided if possible, unless one's social standing is absolutely clear.

The real reason {wIj jup:sen:nolink} has this meaning is because some Star Trek writer looked up "my" and "friend" in {TKD:src}, found {-wIj:n} and {jup:n}, and attached them to each other without any regard for grammar or correctness. In standard Klingon, "my friend" (assuming said friend is a being capable of language) is {jupwI':n:nolink} (from {jup:n} and {-wI':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a stand-alone spike such as a stake.
On the TV show "Buffy the Vampire Slayer", there is a character nicknamed Spike whose real name is William.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to an abstract schematic of a battlefield, which is displayed on a {jIH:n:2}. Contrast this with {HaSta:n}.
The first ever line of Klingon spoken on-screen was {wIy cha'}, in {Star Trek I:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: hurl a spear by means of a {chetvI':n:2}

table.name: mem
table.column: It is regrettable when this is applied to food.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: transgress, do more than is acceptable
{bIwogh:sen:nolink} might be translated "You go too far."

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The noun {woj:n} and the verb {Say'qu'moH:v} appeared next to each other in a word list published in {veS QonoS:src} (reprinted in {HQ 1.3, Sept. 1992:src} in Sept. 1992). Will Martin made an error in transcribing the words, and MO subsequently canonised his error, as a joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for both eating and attacking by pecking.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {wov; ghI'boj Sech rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has appeared in canon only in the formation {wovmoHbogh janHommey:n:nolink}[1; 2], but the noun suffixes have been removed here for ease of reference.
▶ {Qapqu' wovmoHbogh janHommey!:sen:nolink} "It even has working lights!"[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: wo' toy'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.
To die while serving the Empire is the hope of every Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: The son of Mogh ({mogh:n:name}), and the first Klingon officer to serve in Starfleet. He is portrayed by the actor {mayqel Do'rIn:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: An idiomatic way of saying "snore" in English is "saw wood".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Dumer DIvI' QaS 'ej DuHIv, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIrIQchoH.:sen:nolink} "Surprise attack by Federation leaves you unprotected and damaged."[1] ▶ {DuHIv jagh Dangu'laHbe'bogh, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIpujchoH.:sen:nolink} "Attack by unknown enemy leaves you vulnerable and weak."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to undo a decision. Its only known use in canon is in the following example.
{vImuHlu' net wuqHa'!:sen:nolink} "My death sentence was commuted!"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers both to the brain and to "mind, intellect". For the organ, see {QoghIj:n}.
▶ {targhlIj yab tIn law' no'lI' Hoch yabDu' tIn puS!:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon by itself, but can be inferred from {jIb yachwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Klingon has five verbs corresponding to each of the {yaD:n:1,nolink}: {mar:v}, {Hom:v}, {roS:v:2}, {nan:v:2}, and {Qay':v:2}.
Correspondingly, the five toes are {marwI':n}, {HomwI':n}, {roSwI':n}, {nanwI':n:2}, and {Qay'wI':n}.
The toe verbs are used in the same way as the finger verbs, but they are not heard often outside of discussions about martial arts movements or dance, and are normally considered archaic.
The verbs for the toes come from the nursery rhyme "This Little Piggy".

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang word originated from the similarity of {yan:n} and {yaD:n:1} in the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Gamma Quadrant, a part of the Dominion.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not seem to have appeared in canon, but it is obvious by analogy with {nItlhpach:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is in clipped Klingon. In standard Klingon, "Do you understand?" (speaking to one person) would be {bIyaj'a'?:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a weapon with long blades.

table.name: mem
table.column: The members of the {yan 'ISletlh:n:nolink} are the Chancellor's personal bodyguards.
▶ {Qang QanmeH yan 'ISletlh Damuv 'e' wIvlu'.:sen:nolink} "You are chosen to serve on the Yan-Isleth and protect the Chancellor."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined in the body of {KGT:src} on p.61.

table.name: mem
table.column:
There are nine ranks of officers: ▶ {'aj:n} "admiral" ▶ {Sa':n} "general" ▶ {totlh:n} "commodore" ▶ {'ech:n} "brigadier" ▶ {HoD:n} "captain" ▶ {la':n} "commander" ▶ {Sogh:n} "lieutenant" ▶ {lagh:n} "ensign" ▶ {ne':n} "yeoman"
Someone of rank {Sogh:n} or higher can also be referred to as {ra'wI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a gray (sometimes white) bird that can travel particularly long distances without pausing.

table.name: mem
table.column: A pregnant woman is said to {qeng:v} a {puq:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {yay chavlu' 'e' bajnISlu'.:sen} "Victory must be earned."[2, p.125] ▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2, p.211] ▶ {qIbDaq Hoch Hovtay'mey bocharghchugh, yay bochav.:sen:nolink}[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: wrist (also a slang term of deprecation)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an organization dedicated to scholastic pursuits or research. The distinction between {yejHaD:n:nolink} and {yej'an:n} is not clear, but {yejHaD:n:nolink} is usually used for larger organizations.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an organization dedicated to scholastic pursuits or research. The distinction between {yej'an:n:nolink} and {yejHaD:n} is not clear, but {yejHaD:n:nolink} is usually used for larger organizations.[1]
Do not confuse this with a society in the cultural sense, for which see {nugh:n}.[1]
{tlhIngan yej'an:n:nolink} would be "a group dedicated to the study of Klingons"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject is the cooperating parties.
This is missing from the K-E side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote a game square, including those corresponding to the four ship classes.
▶ {nom yer mechmeH Quj} "The Fast-Dealing Property Trading Game"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to the walls of "Jericho".

table.name: mem
table.column: If the command is given to multiple people and the object is none, be careful to use {pe-:v} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {'up; yIH rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also mean "Put her on screen" or "Put it on screen". A shorter way of putting it in English is just "On screen". However, "Put them on screen" would be {tIHotlh.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: feed him, feed her, feed it

table.name: mem
table.column: {yIn nI' yISIQ 'ej yIchep!:sen} "Live long and prosper!"

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word can be used transitively to say things like {tlhIngan yIn DayIn:sen:nolink} "You live a Klingon life."[2]
To say that someone "lives at" a place, use {Dab:v}.

The Klingon sentence {tlhIngan yIn DayIn:sen:nolink} was written by MO in someone's {KGT:src} when he autographed it. It does not actually appear in the {HQ 7.4:src} article, but it is alluded to there by its English translation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a common Vulcan saying.

table.name: mem
table.column: yIntaHbogh qagh jablu'DI' reH nIvqu' qagh.
Gagh is always best when served live.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was used by MO in a "get well" letter.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Don't just aim; hit the target!

table.name: mem
table.column: For example, used to describe a warrior gathering his armour and weapons before a battle.
{nuHmeyDaj may'luchDaj nIv je yIr qeylIS:sen:nolink} "Kahless gathered his weapons and his finest suit of armor"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also spelled "Yridian" in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {KGT p.167:src} for an explanation of this slang word.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word originally referred to a sleeveless garment.
In {TNK:src}, this word is used to translate "shirt", and {yIvbeH SeQHa':n:nolink} is used for "T-shirt".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has this meaning in the {voSpegh Sep:n} dialect.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for gathering plants or plant parts, whether {Du' naH:n} or {naH tlhab:n}. (See {KGT p.89:src}.)

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {A Burning House:src}, this is a Klingon festival to celebrate the end of harvest. Its name literally comes from {yob:v} and {-ta':v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not refer to force fields ({Surchem:n}), for which see {botjan:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for real shields. To "shield oneself" is {yoD'egh}. For force fields, use {botjan:n} with {chu':v:2}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qab yon Da'agh. qablIj yon yI'aghHa' 'aghHa'pa' 'etlhwIj.:sen:nolink} "Scrape that smug look from your face before my blade does it for you."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tlhIngan wo' yuQmey chovlu'chugh Qo'noS potlh law' Hoch potlh puS. roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH. pa' 'oHtaH vaS'a''e'. tlhIngan qum waw' 'oH. yoq yIn yuQ 'oH Qo'noS'e'. yInSIp voQSIp je ngaS muDDaj.:sen:nolink} "The principal planet of the Klingon Empire, Qo'noS is usually referred to as simply "The Homeworld." This is where the Klingon Great Hall is located, the center of the Klingon government. Qo'noS is a class-M planet with an oxygen/nitrogen atmosphere."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not used for a removable top, which would be a {yuvtlhe':n} "lid". The other face of an object's {yor:n:nolink} is called its {'aqroS:n:1}.[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: The verb {yoy:v} does not appear with the suffix {-moH:v} in canon. However, MO approved of {yoymoHwI'} as a bit of technobabble meaning "inverter".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: A fleet consists of more than one {nawlogh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence in which this appeared was actually written with hyphens, like this: {HoD, yo'-SeH yaH-nIv-vo' potlh De' wI-Hev-taH:sen:nolink}, with a newline between {potlh:sen:nolink} and {De':sen:nolink}.[1]
▶ {HoD, yo'SeH yaHnIvvo' potlh De' wIHevtaH.:sen:nolink} "Captain, we are receiving a priority message from Operations Command." This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: first (and last) tone of nonatonic musical scale

The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n:nolink}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.[1]
The first and second {yu:n:nolink} are not an octave apart, but rather a nonave apart.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: husk, rind, peel, shell (of fruit, nut)

table.name: mem
table.column: Humans eat {yuch ngoghmey:n:nolink}, which Maltz finds strange.
{nuqDaq yuch Dapol?:sen:nolink} "Where do you keep the chocolate?"[1, p.172; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {yuDHa'; ghIt rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The United Federation of Planets is often simply called "the Federation" ({DIvI':n}). Another word for it is {yuQjIjQa':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Another word for the United Federation of Planets is {yuQjIjDIvI':n} (often shortened to just {DIvI':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The singular form is never used in place of {tey':n:nolink} or {lor:n:nolink}, but the plural may be used for a group including {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}, so long as there is at least one more distant cousin, niece or nephew in the group.

table.name: mem
table.column: Literally, "push, turn" (how you open a so-called child-proof lid).

table.name: mem
table.column: It may just be a coincidence, but {yu:n} and {'egh:n} are the first and third tones of the Klingon nonatonic musical scale.
This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Both {'ab:v:nolink} and {'aD:v} mean "have a length of", but they are used in different contexts. {'ab:v:nolink} is used for long items and to express height. The object of {'ab:v:nolink} is the length or height of the subject.

▶ {wej 'ujmey 'ab 'oy'naQ.:sen:nolink} "Painstiks are a little over one meter long."[1] ▶ {jav 'ujmey 'ab SuvwI'.:sen:nolink}[2] ▶ {vagh 'ujmey vI'ab.:sen:nolink}[2] ▶ {wej 'uj 'ab naQjej.:sen:nolink}[2]
length, height, long, high, have a length of, have a height of

table.name: mem
table.column: Both {'aD:v:nolink} and {'ab:v} mean "have a length of", but they are used slightly differently. For flat objects such as tabletops, {'aD:v:nolink} is used for one dimension while {juch:v} is used for the other. For long objects, and for height, {'ab:v:nolink} is used instead.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used in the {ma'to'vor:n} ritual. It must be real and not replicated.[1]
[1] {DS9 - Sons of Mogh:src}, [2] {A Good Day to Die:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qab yon Da'agh. qablIj yon yI'aghHa' 'aghHa'pa' 'etlhwIj.:sen:nolink} "Scrape that smug look from your face before my blade does it for you."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a specialized school.[2] (For the most general word for a place of learning, see {DuSaQ:n}.)
This is a reference to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS).

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Federation. Also called {'anDorya':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a name from Shakespeare.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qablIj HI'ang:sen:nolink} "Show me your face!" (see {Hay':v})[2, p.68] ▶ {ro'lIj HI'ang!:sen}[2, p.195]

table.name: mem
table.column: 'ang'eghQo' quv Hutlhbogh jagh neH ghobtaHvIS ghaH.
Only an enemy without honor refuses to show himself in battle.
Only an enemy without honour refuses to show himself in battle.

table.name: mem
table.column: The meaning of this word is unclear. It occurs in {'ul 'aplo':n} and {wab qoSta' 'aplo':n}. It was also originally used to translated "Limited Edition" for {Klingon Monopoly:src}, as {'aplo'mey puS neH chenmoHlu'pu':sen:nolink}, before {'aplo':n:nolink} was changed to {vey:n}. The Klingon version of the list of the game box's "contents" has the heading {ngaS 'aplo':sen:nolink}. This suggests that {'aplo':n:nolink} means something like "container".
There is a typo in {ngaS 'aplo':sen:nolink}: it actually reads {naS 'aplo':sen:nolink} on the box, but it's clear what was meant.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of weapon (half ax, half bat'leth)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a general purpose knife that seems to be able to cut through anything.
The phrase "Act now!" is used repeatedly in TV informercials for Ginsu knives.

table.name: mem
table.column: bottom surface of a table, ceiling
The other face of an object's {'aqroS:n:1,nolink} is its {yor:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used to specify a limit or restriction.
In other contexts, consider using the verb suffix {-qu':v}. For example: {nom yIghoSqu'!:sen:nolink} "Maximum speed!" ({Star Trek V:src})
▶ {'aqroS qughDo - pIvlob Hut vI' vagh:sen:nolink} "Maximum Cruising Speed - Warp 9.5"[1] ▶ {Qapchu'meH 'aqroS chuq:n:nolink} "maximum effective range"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: A character in a famous Klingon opera.

table.name: mem
table.column: This question word follows the noun to which it refers, which never has a plural suffix.

▶ {Haw'pu' yaS 'ar?:sen:nolink} "How many officers fled?" ({TKD p.70:src}) ▶ {nIn 'ar wIghaj?:sen:nolink} "How much fuel do we have?" ({TKD p.70,170:src}) ▶ {Dochvetlh DIlmeH Huch 'ar DaneH?:sen} "How much do you want for that?" ({TKD p.171:src})

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the most common of several ways of asking for the time in Klingon. One can also ask, {'arlogh wab Qoylu'pu'?:sen:nolink} or {qen 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen:nolink} The answer to this question is, for example, {cha'logh Qoylu'pu':sen:nolink} "It has been heard twice", meaning "two o'clock".
Another way is to issue the command, {rep yIper!:sen:nolink} In replying to this command, the hours are numbered and not counted. For example, {rep cha':sen:nolink} is "two o'clock".

table.name: mem
table.column: When an escaped prisoner looks for a guard, he always finds one.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a type of beverage made from (among other things) the {melchoQ:n} of a {teghbat:n}. It has a superficial resemblance to Terran root beer.[1, p.95]
This word refers not to a specific drink, but to a narrow class of related drinks.[2]
"A&W" is a brand of root beer.

table.name: mem
table.column:
An opportunity is said to be captured ({jon:v}), and if one misses an opportunity, it is said to have escaped ({nargh:v:2}).[3] See examples below.
In a Klingon bar, the bartender ({chom:n}) shouts {'eb Qav:n} for "last call".[4]

▶ {jIpaSqu'mo' narghpu' qaSuchmeH 'eb.:sen:nolink} "Because I'm very late, the opportunity to visit you has escaped."[3] ▶ {qaSuch vIneH 'ach narghpu' 'eb. jIpaSqu'.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit you, but the opportunity has escaped. I am very late."[3] ▶ {qaSuchlaHbe'. jIpaSqu' vaj narghpu' 'eb.:sen:nolink} "I cannot visit you. I am very late, thus the opportunity has escaped."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is shouted by the bartender ({chom:n}) at a Klingon bar ({tach:n}) before alcoholic beverages cease to be served.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Quj 'echlet:n:nolink} is used to mean "game board".

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {'echletHom:n:nolink} is used for the various kinds of game cards. In {TNK:src}, {QIn 'echletHom:n} is used to mean "postcard".

table.name: mem
table.column: be landed? be in the air? (aircraft)

This is an unknown element found in {'eDSeHcha:n}. Following the example of {lolSeHcha:n}, this should be a verb related to aircraft landing or take-off. This element or a homophone is also found in {'eDjen:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who is {nguq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is plural. Its singular form is unknown. It appears to consist of the elements {SeH:v} and {cha:n}, or homophones thereof, and an element {'eD:v:hyp} whose meaning is unknown.

table.name: mem
table.column: third tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n:nolink}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.
The third tone of the musical scale is "me", and {-'egh:v:suff} is the "self" suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression indicates that the speaker is about to give a command.

table.name: mem
table.column: The conjunction {'ej:conj} does not have any temporal or sequential implications.[2] To express those meanings, use {ghIq:adv} or {ngugh:adv}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This element is known only from {'ejDo':n} and {'ejyo':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {TKD p.20:src}, it's likely that {Do':n:archaic,hyp} is an archaic word for the modern {Duj:n:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: And the blood was ankle deep (drinking song)

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being entered. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]
▶ {HIq DaSammeH tach yI'el.:sen} ▶ {neHmaH Da'el net tu':sen:nolink} "Caught breaching the Neutral Zone."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: At "By Any Other Name: An Evening of Shakespeare in Klingon", put on by the Washington Shakespeare company, the sign on the will-call tickets window said {'elmeH chaw'mey je'lu'ta'bogh:n:nolink}. This translation was supplied by MO.

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to a Passover custom in which an empty seat is reserved for the prophet Elijah.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is usually made of metal.
This is an "LP", a long-playing music record.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the rear section of an object, see {'o':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a series of Federation starships.
▶ {'entepray' Hub patmey luchu'be'lu'pu'.:sen:nolink} "Enterprise defense systems are down."[2]
[1] {SkyBox 15:src} (reprinted in {HQ 3.4, p.10-11, Dec. 1994:src}), [2] {Star Trek V notes:src} (not actually in the film)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Kyle XY" was an American TV show the title character of which lacks this body part.

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of stick, rope, etc.), other end from {megh'an:n}

This can refer to either end of the rope, stick or whatever, but once you arbitrarily choose an end to call {'er'In:n:nolink}, the other end is called {megh'an:n}. Before you make this initial reference, either end can be called either {'er'In:n:nolink} or {megh'an:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the area in front of an object, see {tlhop:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This could refer to the blade of a knife or spear.

table.name: mem
table.column: Even the best blade will rust and grow dull unless it is cared for.

table.name: mem
table.column: area northwestward, area to the northwest
This is approximately 320 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.
Eva Saint Marie starred in Alfred Hitchcock's "North-by-Northwest".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be good, be delicious, be tasty, be harmonious
This word is applied to food and music.
In English slang, "ey!" is an expression of satisfaction.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for food that has been prepared poorly.[1, p.84]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This pronoun is used as the object of the second sentence in a sentence-as-object construction. It refers to the previous sentence as a whole.
Normally, {net:n:pro} is used when the subject of the verb is indefinite (that is, {X net Y:sen:nolink} is used instead of {X 'e' Y-lu':sen:nolink}). However, this is not always the case. See {net:n:pro} for examples.
Do not confuse this pronoun with the suffix {-'e':n:suff}.
▶ {qama'pu' DIHoH 'e' luSov:sen:nolink} "They know we kill prisoners."[1] ▶ {yaS qIppu' 'e' vIlegh:sen:nolink} "I saw him/her hit the officers."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The child of an {'e'mam:n:nolink} is a {lor:n:1}.
This is a reference to "Auntie Mame", a broadway play.

table.name: mem
table.column: someone who married into the family

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a square or rectangular tub used to hold food while fermenting.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has negative connotations, and is considered quite insulting when applied to a person.[1, p.167]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {voSpegh Sep:n}, this is used instead of {ghaw':n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A particular percussion instrument may be struck with the palm ({toch:n}; the verb is {weq:v}), the fist ({ro':n}; the verb is {tlhaw':v}), or a stick ({mupwI'Hom:n} if it resembles a small hammer, {naQHom:n} if a plain stick; the verb is {moq:v}).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: To make an {'Ip:n} is to {'Ip:v} or {lay':v}; to keep it is to {pab:v} the {'Ip:n}.
▶ {tugh 'Ipvetlh Dapab DaneH'a'?:sen:nolink} "How would you like to keep that promise, very soon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be too much, be too many

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is not exactly the same as {QuchHa':v}, since the latter implies a change from being happy to not being happy.[2]
See {rav:n:2} for an idiom related to sadness.

table.name: mem
table.column: The child of an {'IrneH:n:nolink} is a {lor:n:1}.
This is a reference to Uncle "Henry" from The Wizard of Oz.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word fits into a sentence in the place which would be occupied by the answer.[1] It works like a pronoun in questions with "to be" in the English translations.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This sounds like what a human would say upon seeing blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: I travel the river of blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: May you travel the river of blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is best served at {porgh Hat:n}.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used in the preparation of {qagh:n}.[1, p.87]

table.name: mem
table.column: Blood Oath Circles, name of statue by mIStaq

table.name: mem
table.column: Listen to the voice of your blood.

table.name: mem
table.column: When this toast first appeared in {CK:src}, it was thought that its grammar was incorrect. However, this toast was repeated in {PK:src}, where it was noted that toasts follow special grammar. This grammar was finally explained in {KGT:src} (see under {-jaj:v}).[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: My blood is thicker than yours.
This idiomatic phrase carries the meaning, "I am much stronger than you."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was originally made up by Mark Shoulson to illustrate why people shouldn't make up words, since no one else would understand them. When MO heard about it, he turned it into a real word as a joke.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This isn't an exact translation, but {'I'SeghIm:n:nolink} is the closest Klingon equivalent to the English word "curmudgeon".[1]
This is a reference to "Isegrim" (or "Ysengrimus"), a wolf who is the chief character in a series of fables.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears before a name used as direct address, almost like a vocative prefix.
{'o 'oghlu'meH qul:sen:nolink} "O for a Muse of fire"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: order, group officially recognized by government

table.name: mem
table.column: Parts of an ax include its handle, {DeS:n:2}, and its blade, {ghIt:n:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who puts in pipes (whether for water or for anything else). There is a special word for a pipe that carries water, {qatlhDa':n}, but the person who puts this in is still called an {'och mutlhwI':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word implies the creation of something which has not been created before. In this, it differs from {ren:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Ohm" is the unit of electrical resistance.

table.name: mem
table.column: some, an unknown or unspecified quantity

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
Verbs related to aircraft (or spacecraft) movement include: {Dav:v}, {Der:v}, {jer:v}, {jIm:v}, {lol:v:2}, {ron:v}, {tor:v:2} (def'n 2).
It is unknown if all of these words have meanings outside of the context of aircraft attitude descriptions. However, {ron:v:nolink} can be applied to other objects such as dice (see {mI' nagh:n}), and {lol:v:nolink} and {tor:v:nolink} can be applied to people or animals (see {lol:v:1} (def'n 1) and {tor:v:1} (def'n 1)).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {'orghenya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that this is {'orghengan:n:nolink} and not {'orghenngan:n:nolink} (the {n:sen:nolink} at the end of {'orghen:n:nolink} is dropped).
This word is also written {'orghenya'ngan:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word consists of the first two letters of "Or"ville and "Wi"lbur Wright's names.

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {TKD:src}, [2] {SkyBox 20:src} (reprinted in {HQ 5.2, p.14, Jun. 1996:src}), [3] {SkyBox 31:src} (reprinted in {HQ 6.2, p.9, Jun. 1997:src})

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: If you don't use the painstik, the child will never celebrate his Age of Ascension.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "My little toe aches a lot". See {Qay':v:2} for an explanation.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the area behind an object, see {'em:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {'o' chuyDaH:n:nolink} is located near the {Hongghor:n}. They are listed together as {'o' chuyDaH Hongghor je:n:nolink} on the {BoP:src} poster.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a drum with skin stretched over both ends.[1, p.75]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is only used for songs. The final phrase or portion in other kinds of performances is referred to using {bertlham:n}.
All Klingon songs have {'o'meghmey:n:nolink}. If a song fades away instead of properly ending, as some Federation songs do, the ending of such a song may be called {'o'meghqoq:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This term can be used for "double agent" (for which a slang term is {jey'naS ghoqwI':n}), but its meaning is a bit broader.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {'uD'a':n:nolink} appears in {HQ 1.3, Sept. 1992:src}, where it is also defined as just "laser".

table.name: mem
table.column: have a hangover, be hung over

table.name: mem
table.column:
Based on the measurements given on the {BoP:src} poster, one {'uj:n:nolink} is very close to 34.83 cm.
Three {'uj:n:nolink} is about 3'5", five {'uj:n:nolink} is about 5'8", and six {'uj:n:nolink} is about 6'10".[2]
In {KGT:src}, this unit is described as "about 35 cm".

▶ {wej 'ujmey 'ab 'oy'naQ.:sen:nolink} "Painstiks are a little over one meter long."[3] ▶ {wejvatlh loSmaH loS vI' vagh wej 'uj 'aD Duj:sen:nolink} "Length: 120 M"[4] ▶ {loSmaH jav vI' Soch loS 'uj 'ab meH:sen:nolink} "Bridge Height: 16.28 M"[4] ▶ {HIvtaHvIS toQDuj cha'vatlh wejmaH Soch vI' vagh chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Attack Formation Height: 82.75 M"[4] ▶ {qughtaHvIS toQDuj HutmaH vI' jav wa' 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Cruise Formation Height: 31.56 M"[4] ▶ {SaqtaHvIS toQDuj wa'vatlh loS vI' jav chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Landing Formation Height: 36.46 M"[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: One {'uj'a':n:nolink} is equal to nine {'uj:n:nolink}. However, there is no unit {'ujHom:n:nolink} denoting one-ninth of an {'uj:n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to the "Underwriter's Laboratories". A label with the acronym "UL" is found on all electrical appliances in the US.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears in {TNK:src} only in the plural as {'ul 'aplo'mey:n:nolink} "batteries". Technically, what is commonly called a "battery" is a single cell, and a "battery" is an array ({DaH:n}) of such cells.

table.name: mem
table.column: be unsavory, disgusting, repugnant, loathsome, icky

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just a regular noun-noun construction. It was used as an example in a message on the {msn:src} newsgroup to show that the known vocabulary and existing grammar can be used to say a lot of things which aren't explicitly spelled out.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the K-E side of {TKDA:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a person who commits treason. For a person who betrays someone, see {maghwI':n}.
This is missing from the K-E side of {TKDA:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a noisy bird known to make a ruckus at dawn, which has been likened to a rooster (but is much fiercer than a rooster).
The "leghorn" is a type of chicken, and Foghorn Leghorn is a cartoon leghorn rooster.

table.name: mem
table.column: The "yuzu" plant is used in the creation of some sauces in Asian cuisine.

table.name: mem
table.column: An officer who ended service in retirement.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also the name of an opera, which narrates many of the same events as found in the {paq'batlh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the empty verb prefix. Following the notation in {TKD:src}, it is denoted by {0:v:pref,nolink} here.
Note that the prefix for "they-him/her/it" is {lu-:v:pref}.
he-none, she-none, it-none, he-him, he-her, he-it, she-him, she-her, she-it, he-them, she-them, it-them

table.name: mem
table.column:
The noun formed with {-'a':n:suff,nolink} refers to something that is bigger, more important, or more powerful than the noun without the suffix.
Note that the noun with {-'a':n:suff,nolink} need not be better than the bare noun in every possibly way, just in one way that is significant for that noun. For example, a {mIv'a':n} is not necessarily bigger in size than a {mIv:n}, and a {toy'wI''a':n} is probably worse off in many ways when compared to a {toy'wI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The noun formed with {-Hom:n:suff,nolink} refers to something that is smaller, less important, or less powerful than the noun without the suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a rarely used suffix, which is used to indicate endearment. It is usually attached to a word for a relative, or sometimes an animal such as a pet.
It is suspected that a {qaghwI':n} is inserted before this suffix if the noun ends in a vowel, but no examples are known.
This sounds like the Cantonese word for "love".

table.name: mem
table.column: plural (beings capable of using language) (noun type 2)

This suffix is attached to a noun referring to beings capable of language when there is more than one of that type of being.
Note that whether {-pu':n:suff,nolink} is used is a property of the noun, and not necessarily of the things it is referring to. For example, a group of Klingons rendered unable to speak, or a group of Klingon babies too young to understand language, would still be referred to as {tlhInganpu':n:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix is used to form the plural of body parts, whether they belong to beings capable of language or to any other animal. However, if a body part becomes separated from a being and is transformed into something which is no longer primarily a body part, then {-mey:n:suff,nolink} is used instead. For example, the plural of {veDDIr:n} "pelt" is {veDDIrmey:n:nolink} rather than {veDDIrDu':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
When this suffix is used for beings capable of using language (see {-pu':n}), it adds the notion of "scattered all about" to the meaning. This suffix cannot be used for body parts (see {-Du':n}), but this rule is sometimes violated by poets.
Some nouns are inherently plural in meaning, with singular forms which are utterly distinct. These inherently plural nouns are treated as grammatically singular, in that singular pronouns and verb prefixes are used for them. When the suffix {-mey:n:nolink} is applied to the singular forms of these nouns, the resulting plural word carries the connotation of "scattered all about".
{pu'HIchmey:n:nolink} "phasers", {puqmey:n:nolink} "children all over the place", {jatmey:n:nolink} "scattered tongues", {DoSmey:n:nolink} "targets scattered all about"

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates the noun is being used in a false or ironic fashion.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the speaker thinks the object referred to by the noun is accurately described by it, but has some doubts.

table.name: mem
table.column: Ths suffix indicates that the speaker has no doubt that the object referred to by the noun is accurately described by it.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: my (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: our (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: your (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column: your (plural) (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This indicates that the noun refers to an object which is nearby or which is the topic of the conversation.[1]
For most words designating a fixed period of time, this suffix indicates the current such period: {DISvam:n:nolink} "the current year", {jarvam:n:nolink} "the current month", {Hoghvam:n:nolink} "the current week", etc. However, {jajvam:n} "the current day" is not quite interchangeable with {DaHjaj:n} "today".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This indicates that the noun refers to an object which is not nearby or which is brought up again as the topic of the conversation.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix indicates that an action is occurring (or has occurred or will occur) in the vicinity of the noun to which it is attached.[1] It can typically be used only for physical locations.[2]
Some verbs have locative notions in their meanings, and care must be taken when using {-Daq:n:suff,nolink} with such verbs. See {ghoS:v:1} and {jaH:v} for more details. With verbs of shooting, such as {baH:v} and {bach:v}, {-Daq:n:suff,nolink} marks the target.
When a verb is used adjectivally, this suffix and the other type 5 noun suffixes are attached to the verb rather than the noun. (According to {TKD 4.4:src}, when a verb is used in this way, it can have no other suffix except for {-qu':v:suff}. However, this has been contradicted by subsequent canon, e.g., {SuvwI' quvHa':n:nolink} from {HQ 12.3:src} and {Duj ngaDHa':n} from {KGT:src}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix is used when the action is in a direction away from the noun to which it is attached.[1] It can typically be used only for physical locations.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a verb suffix {-mo':v} with the same meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix indicates the noun to which it is attached is the beneficiary of the action.
It is used to indicate the indirect object when the object is the recipient of the action. ({TKDA 6.8:src})
See {qawmoH:v} for an explanation of how this suffix is used with the verb suffix {-moH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix emphasizes that the noun to which it is attached the topic of the sentence.[1] It is used with the pronouns to form "to be" constructions.[2] It is also used to disambiguate which noun is the head noun in a relative clause (see {-bogh:v}).
If the object noun is marked with {-'e':n:suff,nolink}, it can come before adverbials, which still precede the verb.[3]
To use {-'e':n:suff,nolink} on a series of nouns (i.e., nouns joined with one of {je:conj}, {joq:conj}, or {ghap:conj}), it must be attached to each noun individually.[4] This can happen if there are multiple head nouns in a relative clause, or if the subject of a "to be" construction consists of multiple things.
In the Morskan dialect, this suffix is not used to mark the subject in "to be" constructions. If the suffix is used in such a sentence, it serves its usual function of emphasis.[5]
Do not confuse this suffix with the pronoun {'e':n:pro}.
In {HQ 4.2:src}, this suffix is also described as a focus marker.[4]

▶ {lujpu' jIH'e'.:sen:nolink} "I, and only I, have failed." or "It is I who has failed."[1] ▶ {pa'DajDaq ghaHtaH la''e'.:sen:nolink} "The commander is in his quarters."[2] ▶ {cheng'e' DaH Sam!:sen:nolink} "Find Chang!" (clipped)[6] ▶ {Paramount Pictures malja' permey bIH Star Trek pong'e' Deghmey'e' je.:sen:nolink}[7]
[1] {TKD 3.3.5:src}, [2] {TKD 6.3:src}, [3] {TKDA 6.7:src}, [4] {HQ 4.2, p.5-6, Jun. 1995:src}, [5] {KGT p.23:src}, [6] {Star Trek VI:src}, [7] {SkyBox cards:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: When this suffix is used, the verb prefix must indicate "no object".
verb type 1, I-me, you-you, he-him, she-her, it-it, we-us, they-them

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix is only used with plural subjects. When this suffix is used, the verb prefix must indicate "no object".

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the subject needs to do the action.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the subject is willing to perform the action.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {ghuS:v} never takes the suffix {-rup:v:suff,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ready, set up (referring to devices) (verb type 2)

table.name: mem
table.column: It is culturally taboo to use this suffix with a first person subject.
The unstated exception to the rule is that it is not taboo if {-vIp:v:suff,nolink} is negated with {-be':v:suff}, as illustrated by the sentences on {TKD:src} p.49.

table.name: mem
table.column: change in state, change in direction (verb type 3)

This suffix indicates that the action described by the verb involves a change from the state of affairs as it existed before the action took place. The English translation of this suffix may be "become" or "begin to".

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix implies that the action had been taking place, then stopped, and then began again.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use this with a verb which takes an object.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the subject is unknown, indefinite, or general. It is used only with prefixes which normally indicate a third-person singular object ({vI-:v}, {Da-:v}, {wI-:v}, {bo-:v}, and {lu-:v}). When used with this suffix, these prefixes change in meaning so that instead of indicating the person and number of the subject, they indicate the person and number of the object instead.
{batlh Daqawlu'taH.:sen} "You will be remembered with honor."

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with some verbs of fighting, this suffix implies that the fighting results in death (see {Suvchu':v}, {Hay'chu':v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the speaker thinks the assertion is obvious to the listener.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix expresses uncertainly on the speaker's part. It may be translated as "I think" or "I suspect".

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that an action is completed.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix indicates that an action is completed, and the activity was deliberately undertaken.
There is a special verbal construction, {rIntaH:v}, which denotes a similar meaning, but has the further connotation of finality.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the action is ongoing.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix indicates that the action is ongoing, and is proceeding towards a known goal or stopping point.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix is used infrequently by Klingons. It usually expresses extreme politeness or deference, and is used only in addressing a superior.[1]
This suffix is also used with some verbs of fighting to indicate that the verb refers to a suicide attack. For example, {HIvneS} implies that suicide is part of the attack plan, and similarly, {HubneS} implies that suicide is part of the defense plan.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is always used with the type 7 suffix {-taH:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a noun suffix {-mo':n} with the same meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: for, for the purpose of, in order to (verb type 9)

The purpose clause always precedes the noun or verb whose purpose it is describing.[1]
There is an article in {HQ 7.3:src} which examines {-meH:v:suff,nolink} clauses modifying nouns.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix expresses a desire or wish on the part of the speaker that something take place in the future.[1]
This suffix is attached to the verb in toasts, which always comes last except in the dialects of {Sa'Qej Sep:n} and {noHva'Dut Sep:n}.[2]
When this suffix is used, there is allegedly never a Type 7 aspect suffix.[1] However, this "rule" is contradicted by canon, e.g., {wo' DevtaHjaj ghawran}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: one who does/is, thing which does/is (verb type 9)

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix is not generally used on a verb without another suffix, or on one with a prefix. When it is attached to a stative verb, it gives a meaning like "-ness", while on an active verb it means something like "-tion".[2]

▶ {lo'laHghach} "value"[1] ▶ {lo'laHbe'ghach} "worthlessness"[1] ▶ {naDHa'ghach} "discommendation"[1] ▶ {naDqa'ghach} "re-commendation"[1] ▶ {tlhutlhtaHghach} "ongoing drinking", "the process of continuing to drink"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This follows the concept it negates. It cannot be used in imperatives (use {-Qo':v} instead), but can be applied to verbs used as adjectives.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix is used to denote refusal. It is also used in imperatives. It always occurs last, unless followed by a type 9 suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix indicates that something that was previously done is now undone, or that something is done wrongly. Despite being classified as a rover, this suffix occurs immediately after the verb, before any other suffixes.[1]
This suffix can also be applied to some adverbials, but not to all of them.[2; 3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This suffix emphasizes whatever immediately precedes it.
It can follow verbs used adjectivally, in which case it means "very".
